Course: Fundamentals of Software Engineering (SSW 540)
    Semester: Fall 2024
    Credits: 3
    Instructor: Dr. Y. Morgan
    Description: This course introduces the subject of software engineering from a quantitative, analytic- and metrics-based point of view.
    Learning Outcomes: Understanding the consequential issues when the proper software engineering methods are ignored. Understand the impact of requirements and architecture planning on software development. Able to evaluate newer methods and practices in software engineering.
    Prerequisites:  Software Engineering by Ian Sommerville. The Mythical Man-month: Essays on Software Engineering by F.P. Brooks.  Logbook Assignment - At least 10 entries in Microsoft Word or '.txt' format due by the end of the 12th week. Team problem assignment - Each half of the course includes a 2-week assignment.  participation: 25% assignments: 10% exams: 25% (Midterm), 40% (Final) quizzes: 25% final: 40%  attendance: Attendance will be taken in every class. Students are responsible for all assigned work if they miss a class. late_work: Assignments must be submitted on time; late submissions will be rejected. academic_integrity: Plagiarism is intolerable; violations will result in no points for the assignment and a reduction in letter grade. accommodations: Students needing accommodations should discuss this with the instructor during the first week of classes.

Course: Leading Creative Collaboration (MGT 695 A)
    Semester: Fall 2022
    Credits: 
    Instructor: Nancy Ancowitz
    Description: This course builds individual awareness of creativity and collaboration skills while increasing your capacity for both.
    Learning Outcomes: Communicate the value of enhancing a group’s or organization's creative and collaborative skills and mentor others to build and use these skills at work Design and facilitate effective group ideation and problem-solving events Confidently engage others in productive creative abrasion to make the best use of the diversity of perspectives on a team Motivate yourself and others to address problems that have long been tolerated or accepted as unsolvable attributes of the status quo Assess key attributes of an organization's culture so you can influence the architectural, interpersonal, and philosophical systems that undermine innovation Set personal standards and priorities for yourself as leaders committed to exceptional group creativity and collaboration, and monitor your own continued practice and growth Lead others to address meaningful problems and possibilities everywhere you find them
    Prerequisites: MGT 612 Introduction - Part 1 (WHAT) Introduction - Part 2 (WHAT) What is Creative Collaboration? - Part 1 (WHAT) What is Creative Collaboration? - Part 2 (WHAT) The Brain and Play (WHAT) Organizational Climate vs. Organizational Culture (SO WHAT) Inclusion - Part 1 (SO WHAT) Inclusion - Part 2 (SO WHAT) One-on-One Collaboration Tactics - Part 1 (SO WHAT) One-on-One Collaboration Tactics - Part 2 (SO WHAT) Integrating Collaborative Practices at Work - Part 1 (NOW WHAT) Integrating Collaborative Practices at Work - Part 2 (NOW WHAT) Reflection, Gratitude, Class Redesign (NOW WHAT) Applied Improvisation: Leading, Collaborating and Creating Beyond the Theatre by Dudeck, T. R. and McClure, C.. The Surprising Power of Liberating Structures: Simple Rules to Unleash a Culture of Innovation by Lipmanowicz, H. and McCandless, K..  Moonwalk 1: Lead an exercise outside of class – post a video testimonial. Team A facilitates all-class activity. Team B facilitates all-class activity. Sandbox Time: Happens outside class and share in learning journal. Moonwalk 2 Design: Design 3 collaboration activities you’ll lead outside class. Team C facilitates all-class activity. Team D facilitates all-class activity. Moonwalk 2: Delivery—Lead 3 collaboration activities outside of class and respond to reflection questions in your learning journal. Self-Reflection Insights and Implications. Final Quiz.  participation: 15 points assignments: 10 points for Moonwalk 1, 10 points for Team A, 10 points for Team B, 10 points for Team C, 10 points for Team D, 20 points for Moonwalk 2 exams: 15 points for Final Quiz  attendance: 0 points if you miss more than 2 classes. academic_integrity: You must cite all references for your written ideas and use quotation marks for all direct quotes from other resources.

Course: Mathematical Foundations of Machine Learning (CS 556)
    Semester: Fall 2023
    Credits: 
    Instructor: Prof. Erisa Terolli
    Description: This course will give a rigorous introduction to the mathematical foundations of machine learning, including but not limited to frequently used tools in linear algebra, calculus, probability, and widely applied methods such as linear regression and support vector machines.
    Learning Outcomes: apply basic concepts in linear algebra to problems in machine learning apply principal component analysis to analyze high-dimensional data apply gradient descent to solve general optimization problems apply linear regression to solve real-world problems use numpy to solve machine learning problems such as recommender systems
    Prerequisites: Vectors and Matrices System of Linear Equations Vector Spaces and Subspaces Orthogonality and Projections Matrix Decomposition Principle Component Analysis Derivatives + Optimization Midterm Review Gradient Descent Probability Theory Probability Distributions Linear Regression Logistic Regression Introduction to Linear Algebra by Gilbert Strang. Probability and Statistics for Engineering and the Sciences by Jay Devore. Calculus by . Course: Sustainable Energy (ME514WS/MT514WS)
    Semester: Summer 2024
    Credits: 
    Instructor: H. Hadim
    Description: Topics in this course include current and potential future energy systems, fuel resources, conversion of resources, and end-use, with emphasis on meeting local and global energy needs in the 21st century in a sustainable manner.
    Learning Outcomes: Students will be able to assess the performance and basic design of various energy conversion systems including traditional (combustion and nuclear) and alternative (solar, wind, hydrogen, etc.) approaches. Students will become familiar with environmental issues related to the greenhouse effect and global climate change. Students will perform comparative analysis of various energy conversion systems. The main criteria used for comparison include economic, social acceptability and environmental consequences.
    Prerequisites: Introduction Systems Tools for Energy Systems Economic Tools, Climate Change Models Fossil Fuel Resources Combustion Carbon Sequestration Nuclear Energy Mid-Term Exam Solar Energy Wind Energy Bioenergy and Transportation Energy Creating 21st Century Energy System Term Project Due Energy Systems Engineering, Evaluation & Implementation by Frances M. Vanek and Louis D. Albright.  Homework will be assigned weekly. No late submission will be accepted. Project Statement due on June 9. Progress Reports due on July 21. Final Report due on August 21.  assignments: 35% exams: 30% projects: 35%  late_work: No late submission will be accepted. academic_integrity: Students must abide by the Stevens Honor System.

Course: Engineering Programming: Python (AAI/CPE/EE 551)
    Semester: Spring 2023
    Credits: 
    Instructor: Dr. Kevin Ryan
    Description: This course presents tools, techniques, algorithms, and programming techniques using the Python programming language for data intensive applications and decision making.
    Learning Outcomes: learn how to design and program python applications. learn how to use lists, tuples, and dictionaries in python programs. learn how to write loops and decision statements in python. learn how to read and write files in python. extract and analyze data in python. learn how to use indexing and slicing to access data in python programs. prepare for their future career in Technology related fields.
    Prerequisites: Basic knowledge of programming Introduction to the Python Programming Language Introducing Python Object Types Numeric Types The Dynamic Typing Interlude String Fundamentals Lists and Dictionaries Tuples Assignments Expressions if Statements while and for loops iterations and comprehensions Function Basics Scopes Arguments Advanced Function Topics Comprehensions and Generations The Benchmarking Interlude Modules: The Big Picture Module Coding Basics Module Packages OOP: The Big Picture Class Coding Basics Midterm Exam (and perhaps a short lecture) OOP: A More Realistic Example Class Coding Details Operator Overloading Designing with Classes Exception Basics Exception Coding Details Exception Objects Data Structures: Linked List Data Structures: Stacks and Queues Popular Python libraries: Numpy, pandas Final Exam Learning Python by Mark Lutz.  An individual Python programming project.  assignments: 40% exams: 20% projects: 20% final: 20%  attendance: Attendance is optional for our weekly Zoom lectures. Course: Business Analytics: Data, Models and Decisions (BIA 500)
    Semester: Summer 2023
    Credits: 3
    Instructor: Bei Yan
    Description: This course explores data-driven methods that are used to analyze and solve complex business problems.
    Learning Outcomes: Utilize the appropriate data-centric software tools and techniques. Develop and apply data-driven methods to analyze and solve complex business problems. Interpret the output of tools and techniques and run simulation sensitivity analyses to improve business decisions. Assess opportunities for creating value using data-driven decision-making. Develop actionable business decisions through combined methodologies and developed systems.

    Semester: Spring 2023
    Credits:

    Description: Applied Analytics is intended to reinforce the understanding of analysis as a way to build models that can focus attention on parts of the system that can be improved through intervention.

Course: Optimization and Process Analytics (BIA 650)
    Semester:  
    Credits: 
    Instructor: Alkis Vazacopoulos
    Description: This course covers basic concepts in optimization and heuristic search with an emphasis on process improvement and optimization.
    Learning Outcomes: Develop and solve optimization models in a number of domains such as supply chain modeling, marketing, production, asset management, capital budgeting, and financial portfolio analysis. Analyze optimization models arising in data analysis. Develop simulation models and design simulation experiments. Perform process mining on workflow logs. Comprehend optimization models that arise in machine learning and deploy appropriate optimization methods.
    Prerequisites: Introduction to Optimization Linear Optimization Linear Optimization Models: Examples and Excel Solver Network Optimization Integer Optimization Nonlinear Optimization Heuristic Algorithms Multi-Objective Optimization Optimization Under Uncertainty Optimization Via Simulation Optimization in Data Analysis Case Studies Student Final Project Presentations Practical Management Science by Wayne L. Winston and S. Christian Albright.  HW #1 Assigned in Module 1, due by the end of Module 3. HW #2 Assigned in Module 4, due by the end of Module 5. Course: Supply Chain Analytics (BIA-674)
    Semester:  
    Credits: 3
    Instructor: Dr. Alkis Vazacopoulos
    Description: Supply Chain Management introduces the tactical and strategic issues surrounding the design and operation of supply chains, to develop supply chain analytical skills for solving real-life problems.
    Learning Outcomes: Assess the goals for the supply chain to interpret the impact of supply chain decisions on the success of a global company. Determine the major drivers of supply chain performance and calculate key metrics that track the performance of the supply chain. Develop analytic methodologies to extract knowledge and business intelligence from the dynamic information about future demand, available production capacity, and sources of supply. Develop models and utilize optimization methods for facility location, network design decisions, transportation optimization, aggregate planning, inventory optimization using Excel Solver and Decision Analysis tools. Construct actionable business decisions using retail sales data, value product availability, and make pricing and inventory decisions. Assess opportunities using procurement and vendor data, perform spend analysis and make sourcing decisions. Assess risk in the supply chain and develop methodologies to reduce risk by using simulation and scenario-based modeling.

text:
Course: Temporary Structures for Heavy Construction (CM-581)
    Semester: Fall 2024
    Credits: 
    Instructor: Paula J. Loomis, PhD, FAIA, FSAME, AICP, LEED AP, SAP
    Description: Temporary structures, in construction, are those that are erected and used to aid in the construction of permanent structures. They are used in constructing buildings, bridges, tunnels and various other structures. This course explains how to design, operate, manage, cost, and oversee the safety of temporary structures. It also covers legal and insurance aspects.
    Learning Outcomes: Demonstrate how to manage the design, erection, use and de-construction of a temporary structure utilizing advanced cost, time, quality and safety controls. Analyze potential safety risks associated with temporary structures and how to mediate those risks in traditional and risky climates. Understand the contractual arrangements for temporary structures and associated cost and risk implications. Exhibit consistent use of integrative thinking.
    Prerequisites: Introduction to Class/Professional and Business Practices Discuss syllabus and outline of class Discuss project Lecture on professional and business practices (Chapter 1) Class presentation on standards, codes and regulations Presentation by Richard Paradis on standards and codes development Standards, Codes and Regulations (Chap 2) Finish Chapter 2 presentation Begin Chapter 3 presentation Presentation: Codes by Richard Paradis Construction and Environmental Loads (Chap 3) Class presentation on construction and environmental loads Presentation on construction in Antarctica Safety and Legal (Chap 4) (Chap 5) Class presentation on safety and legal Presentation by Larry Conners on real-life failures Environmental Issues and Failures of Temporary Structures (Chap 23) Class presentation on temporary structures Presentation on the Grand Canyon Overlook Mid-term Student Presentations (2). Chapter 6, Cofferdams; Chapter 7 and Earth Retaining Structures Discussion on 3-D imagery in construction by David Leonard Student Presentations (2). Chapter 8 Diaphragms and Chapter 9 Construction Dewatering Student Presentations (2). Chapter 10, Underground Tunneling; and Chapter 11, Underpinning Student Presentations (3). Chapter 12, Roadway Decking; Chapter 13, Construction Ramps; and Chapter 14 Scaffolding Student Presentations. Chapter 15, Falsework; Chapter 16, Concrete Formwork; and Chapter 17, Bracing and Guying Student Presentations. Chapter 18, Bridge Falsework; Chapter 19, Temporary Structures for Restoration; and Chapter 20, Cranes Student Presentations and Final Exam Review. Chapter 21, Protection of Site and Chapter 22, Leading Edge Temporary Structure in Construction by Robert Ratay, Editor-in-Chief.     Semester: Fall 2022
    Credits:

    Description: The course will give an introduction to the financial markets for equity, FX, interest rates, commodities and credit, and their derivatives.

Course: Introduction to VLSI Design ()
    Semester: Spring 2024
    Credits: 
    Instructor: Professor Zhuo Feng
    Description: This course provides introductions to various design aspects of modern integrated circuits, as well as related modeling and analysis techniques.
    Learning Outcomes: Be able to develop transistor level circuit diagrams for CMOS digital gates, storage components and arithmetic operators and be able to estimate their performance. Understand the operation of the MOS transistor and its application to CMOS digital design and understand the tradeoffs between performance, noise margin and power dissipation. Know how to layout full custom CMOS circuits obeying process design rules and evaluate the function and performance of these circuits using commercially available circuit simulation tools (SPICE). Understand the CMOS fabrication process and the relationship between layout and mask based fabrication. Know how to design transistor-level digital circuits using a number of different circuit techniques including static compound, pseudo-NMOS and dynamic gates and understand the tradeoffs in performance, area and power dissipation.
    Prerequisites: Introduction to VLSI Design CMOS Fabrication & Layout MOS Transistors and CMOS Logic DC and Transient Response Logic Effort Power Estimation Midterm Exam Interconnect SPICE Circuit Simulation Combinational Logic Sequential Logic SRAM Packaging, Power and Clock Distr. filename: CS 549 Distributed Systems and Cloud Computing - Summer 22 - Syllabus.json
text:
Course: Distributed Systems and Cloud Computing (CS 549)
    Semester: Summer 2022
    Credits: 3
    Instructor: Dominic Duggan
    Description: The objective of this course is to give students a basic grounding in designing and implementing distributed and cloud systems.
    Learning Outcomes: Develop distributed and Web services, using programming paradigms such as client-server, streaming, peer-to-peer, event-driven, and REST. Explain protocols for achieving agreement in distributed systems, such as Two Phase Commit (2PC) and Paxos, and explain their application in scenarios such as transactional e-commerce and cloud infrastructure. Explain methods for building highly available services, and explain the trade-off between weak and strong consistency as given in the CAP theorem. Develop cloud applications using frameworks such as Cassandra, Hadoop, Pig, and Hive. Describe implementation methods and protocols for distributed storage systems: distributed file systems, distributed hash tables, cloud storage, and NoSQL databases.
    Prerequisites: You are expected to have a certain amount of programming maturity, since you will be developing distributed programs during the course of the term. You should know Java since that will be the language for the assignments. Introduction to Distributed Systems and Cloud Computing Client-Server Computing Distributed File Systems Web Services and Failure Models Time and Ordering of Events Asynchronous Communication Transactions Distributed Transactions MapReduce; High Availability Cloud Computing: Hadoop, Pig Consensus Protocols: Paxos, PBFT Blockchain Protocols Eventual Consistency and NoSQL BASE: An ACID Alternative by Dan Pritchett. BigTable: A Distributed Storage System for Structured Data by F. Chang et al.. Keeping CALM: When Distributed Consistency is Easy by J. Hellerstein and P. Alvaro. Cassandra: A Decentralized Structured Storage System by A. Lakshman, P. Malick. Distributed snapshots: Determining global states of distributed systems by K. M. Chandy, L. Lamport. Dynamo: Amazon’s Highly Available Key-value Store by G. DeCandia et al.. End-to-end arguments in system design by J. H. Saltzer, D. P. Reed, D. D. Clark. Above the clouds: A Berkeley view of Cloud Computing by D. A. Patterson et al.. The Google file system by S. Ghemawat, H. Gobioff, S-T. Shun-Tak Leung. Consensus on transaction commit by J. Gray, L. Course: Computer Organization and Programming (CS 550)
    Semester:  
    Credits: 
    Instructor: Reza Peyrovian
    Description: This course provides an intensive introduction to material on computer organization and assembly language programming required for entrance into the graduate program in Computer Science or Computer Engineering.
    Learning Outcomes: Understand how a computer program written in high-level language, such as C, along with its data can be translated into binary machine language and stored as binary numbers, leading to the concept of stored-program computer. Understand how other forms of data, such as decimal or real numbers, are represented, and how hardware follows arithmetic algorithms (such as add and multiply) to perform these operations. Understand the internal structure of the CPU to accomplish load, store, arithmetic, and branching using program counter, registers, and various memory addressing modes. Understand the difference between pipelined and un-pipelined CPUs, their data paths and control paths, and measuring CPU performance. Understand the fundamentals of memory hierarchy and the role of caches in speeding instruction execution and measuring and improving performance of caches. Write programs in assembly language involving loops, branching, and subroutine; compile and execute them.
    Prerequisites: Undergraduates need permission from their advisor. Computers and Technology Integrated Circuits Instruction Set Computer Operations Addressing and Assembly Language Computer Arithmetic and Circuit Design Processor Datapath and Implementation Pipelining and Pipeline Implementation Hazards and Exceptions Memory Technology and Hierarchy Caches Parallel Processors Network Topologies zyBook CS 550 Computer Organization and Design with ARM by . Course: Agile Methods for Software Development (CS 555)
    Semester:  
    Credits: 
    Instructor: Dr. Richard Ens
    Description: This course examines agile methods, including Extreme Programming (XP), Scrum, Lean, Crystal, Dynamic Systems Development Method and Feature-Driven Development to understand how rapid realization of software occurs most effectively.
    Learning Outcomes: Compare and contrast several agile methods for software development. Compare and contrast the origins and motivations of the Agile Manifesto vs. historical methodologies. Refactor code and tests to meet changing needs. Develop and monitor project backlogs. Measure and monitor velocity of development. Compare and contrast plan-driven versus agile methods.

Course: Data Structures (CS 570)
    Semester:  
    Credits: 3
    Instructor: Reza Peyrovian
    Description: This course introduces the most commonly used data structures, as well as sorting algorithms, using the Java programming language.
    Learning Outcomes: Understand the notion of Abstract Data Types, and their use in object-oriented designs. Calculate the Big O of diverse non-recursive algorithms and use it to compare efficiency. Use and understand Collection class in Java, with major emphasis on Lists, Stacks and Queues. Implement double linked lists in Java. Implement Binary Search Trees, Max/Min-Heaps, Priority Queues in Java, and understand the basic concepts of self-balancing Binary Search Trees. Understand Sets and Maps, and more specifically implement hash tables in Java. Understand, and implement recursive algorithms, and data structures. Combine different classes together to implement big programming assignments in Java that combine some of the data structures studied in class.

Course: Digital Signal Processing (EE/CpE 548)
    Semester:  
    Credits: 
    Instructor: Hongbin Li
    Description: Review of mathematics of signals and systems including sampling theorem, Fourier transform, z-transform, Hilbert transform; algorithms for fast computation: DFT, DCT computation, convolution; filter design techniques: FIR and IIR filter design, time and frequency domain methods, window method and other approximation theory based methods; structures for realization of discrete time systems: direct form, parallel form, lattice structure and other state-space canonical forms (e.g., orthogonal filters and related structures); roundoff and quantization effects in digital filters: analysis of sensitivity to coefficient quantization, limit cycle in IIR filters, scaling to prevent overflow, role of special structures.
    Learning Outcomes: Apply mathematical knowledge including Fourier transform and z-transform to solve digital signal processing problems. Use convolution, filtering, sampling and other related engineering principles to analyze digital signals and digital systems. Apply filter design techniques to design digital finite-duration impulse response (FIR) and infinite-duration impulse response (IIR) filters. Use DSP software (e.g., Matalb) to simulate digital signals and systems, perform filtering, and design digital filters.

Mitra.   assignments: 10% exams: 80% projects: 10% final: 40%  attendance: Students should attend all lectures and be responsible for all announcements made in class. late_work: No late work will be accepted without prior approval. academic_integrity: Graduate students in 500-level courses are bound by the Graduate Student Code of Academic Integrity. accommodations: Stevens Institute of Technology is dedicated to providing appropriate accommodations to students with documented disabilities.

text:
Course: Analytical Methods in Electrical Engineering (EE 602)
    Semester: Fall 2024
    Credits: 
    Instructor: Shirantha Welikala
    Description: This course focuses on introducing fundamental concepts and techniques in linear algebra together with their applications to state space analysis.
    Learning Outcomes: Decompose a matrix into its LU decomposition using elementary operations. Solve linear algebraic equations using elementary operation and the reduced row-echelon form. Collaborate effectively in teams to solve complex theoretical problems in linear algebra. Carry out matrix operations including matrix multiplication and matrix inverse, and to calculate matrix determinant using different approaches. Represent a linear time-invariant system into its state space form and calculate the solution to the state space equation. Use linear algebraic techniques to analyze electrical/mechanical systems and predict their behavior. Diagonalize square matrices and find similarity transformations by means of eigenvalues and eigenvectors. Use MATLAB and least squares techniques to analyze data taken from an electrical/mechanical system. Recognize and achieve high levels of professionalism in work and understand subject-related ethical concerns and obligations.
    Prerequisites: Freshman Year Calculus No Classes (Labor Day!) course_title: Introduction to Deep Learning for Engineering
text:
Course: Introduction to Deep Learning for Engineering (EE628WS)
    Semester: Fall 2023
    Credits: 
    Instructor: Rensheng Wang
    Description: This course covers the comprehensive introductions about deep learning techniques used by practitioners in industry and programming exercises with related deep learning software packages. It consists of three sections. The first part reviews the applied math and machine learning basics. The second part studies the industry practices with deep networks in convolutional networks, recurrent & recursive nets, regularization for deep learning, auto-encoders etc. The last one is to train the students with real industry data for deep learning tasks at the big-data platform. By the end of the course, students will have a thorough knowledge about the state-of-the-art approaches used in deep learning.
    Learning Outcomes: 
    Prerequisites: Introduction of machine learning, deep learning and big data platform Introduction of natural language processing (NLP) Neural network basics Train/test sets Bias/variance Regularizing your neural network Overfitting Dropout regularization Normalization Gradient checking Optimization for deep learning Mini-batch gradient descent Exponentially weighted averages RMSprop Adam Optimization Hyperparameter tuning for deep learning Batch normalization Multi-class classification Convolutional Networks Convolution Pooling Structured outputs NLP: language modeling n-gram language models Sequence tagging with probabilistic models NLP: word and sentence embeddings Matrix factorization word2vec Midterm Autoencoders & Variational autoencoder Autoencoder for clustering & anomaly detection Data augmentation Sequence: Modeling recurrent & recursive nets Deep recurrent networks Recursive neural networks Autoencoders & Variational autoencoder Autoencoder for clustering & anomaly detection Sequence: Modeling recurrent & recursive nets RNN to Transformer Transformer II (attention mechanism) Self-attention Multi-header GenAI /Large Language Models ChaGPT and prompt engineering Deep Learning by Ian Goodfellow, Yoshua Bengio, and Aaron Courville. Deep Learning with Python by Francois Chollet.   assignments: 30% exams: 20% projects: 30% final: 20%  academic_integrity: All Stevens graduate students promise to be fully truthful and avoid dishonesty, fraud, misrepresentation, and deceit of any type in relation to their academic work. Course: Engineering Economics and Cost Analysis (EM 600)
    Semester:  
    Credits: 3
    Instructor: Chong Ee
    Description: Engineering Economics and Cost Analysis is an integral part of the Engineering Management program because it is focused on applications of economics and finance in making effective engineering decisions.
    Learning Outcomes: Discover the analysis of financial data, the concept of interest rates and time value of money. Assess between alternative projects using a set of basic tools and techniques of engineering analysis, including the time value of money, internal rate of return and benefit cost ratio. Examine advanced engineering economics topics like depreciation of assets, after tax cash flows and inflation. Apply important decision-making tools like sensitivity analysis, risk analysis and simulation.
    Prerequisites: Introduction to Engineering Economics Accounting and Financial Decision Making Interest Rate and Economic Equivalence Understanding Money and Its Management Present Worth Analysis Annual Equivalent-Worth Analysis Return of Rate Analysis Cost Concepts Relevant to Decision Making Depreciation and Corporate Taxes Developing Cash Flow Analysis Project Risk and Uncertainty Inflation and its Impact on Project Cash Flows Economic Analysis in the Service Sector Contemporary Engineering Economics by Park, C.. text:
Course: Project Management of Complex Systems (EM 612)
    Semester: Spring 2024
    Credits: 3
    Instructor: John Mikruk
    Description: Project Management of Complex Systems is a project-based course that exposes students to tools and methodologies useful for the effective management of systems engineering and engineering management projects.
    Learning Outcomes: Evaluate guidelines, principles, and tools of project management. Analyze factors in creating a project organization, culture, and team. Adapt quantitative techniques to project planning, risk, performance, and monitoring, including stakeholder management. Differentiate between waterfall and agile development benefits and costs in specific environments involving both software and hardware development as well as top-down versus distributed management hierarchical control structures. Examine interdependencies in the project management of complex systems versus those in obvious, complicated, and chaotic systems using an analytical framework.
    Prerequisites: Overview of Project Management Why Project Fail? System Engineering and Bounding Project Scope Work Breakdown Structure Organizing for PM Organizational Structures Project Planning Complexity Estimating and Budgeting Decisions Framework Risk and Opportunity Management Contracting and Sub-contracting Project Assessment and Control Leading and managing the Project Team Project Quality Management Evaluating and closing out a Project Reinventing Project Management: The Diamond Approach to Successful Growth and Innovation by Shenhar and Dvir. Course: Data Analysis and Visualization Techniques for Decision-Making (EM 622)
    Semester: Summer 2023
    Credits: 
    Instructor: Sergio Luna
    Description: This course provides a hands-on introduction to the modern techniques for visualizing data and leverages such techniques with the corresponding problem-solving skills necessary to complement data visualization into specific strategic decision making.
    Learning Outcomes: Determine appropriate visualization charts based on data attributes and analysis. Assess data-driven projects by evaluating data analytics frameworks and the respective lifecycle phases. Analyze projects through the lens of critical thinking by answering 5WH questions, and contextualizing the 'so-what'. Create Python scripts to develop visualization charts. Generate data-driven insights by loading, cleaning, transforming, and visualizing datasets using Python. Develop static and interactive charts to visualize scenarios such as change over time, spatial visualizations, distribution and variation, correlation, magnitude by category, part-to-whole, network graphs, and text data. Formulate a data analytics project manuscript and presentation describing clear project objectives, explaining the data analytics process implemented, and summarizing the study into key insights and recommendations for stakeholders.
    Prerequisites: Orientation and Introductions Recap of Python Data Manipulation 1 Data Manipulation 2 Developing Basic Charts Enhancing Basic Graphs Midterm Project - Storytelling Spatial Data and Time Series Interactive Visualizations & Heatmaps Interactive Visualizations: Introduction to Dashboards Text Analysis Visualization Network Graphs Working with Image Data Data points: visualization that means something by Nathan Yau. filename: F2024 CM-EN545WS Environmental Impact Assessment and Planning Syllabus.json
text:
Course: Environmental Impact Assessment and Planning (EN/CM545WS)
    Semester: Fall 2024
    Credits: 3
    Instructor: Karim S. Karam
    Description: The built environment, while necessary for economic growth, and improving quality of life impacts our physical, cultural and socioeconomic environment, as well as the natural environment. The first part of the course is concerned with environmental planning techniques and strategies. Topics include the management of sustainability, environmental governance and the changing role of civil society, through integrated assessments combining environmental impact assessments (EIA) with cost benefit and risk assessments. The second part of the course is concerned with planning and designing sustainable infrastructure systems. Topics include sustainability rating systems for vertical and horizontal infrastructure, and sustainable project financing. The course includes case studies from around the world.
    Learning Outcomes: Understand the potential impact of development on environmental quality, social well-being and the regional economy Utilize and explain environmental assessment methods used to quantify and analyze these impacts, by developing Environmental Impact Statements Perform systematic socio-economic and environmental cost benefit analyses, and risk assessment, and understand the challenges involved. Plan and design sustainable infrastructure systems by understanding and making use of sustainability rating systems
    Prerequisites: Senior or graduate status or permission from the instructor Introduction: Getting to know each other Human Impact on the Environment Population Growth, Natural Resources, Climate Change United Nations Sustainability Goals, Need for Sustainable Planning Air Pollution, Water Pollution and Treatment Impact of Buildings Environmental Policy Acts The National Environmental Policy Act (NEPA) The Clean Air and Clean Water Acts Environmental Impact Assessments Environmental Impact Statements (EISs) Environmental Impact Reports (EIRs) Environmental Justice Environmental Cost-Benefit Analysis Cost-Benefit Analysis Key Challenges Case Study: Crossing the Hudson River Environmental Risk Assessment and Decision Making Risk Assessment Risk Perception The Role of the Public Case Study: Keystone XL Pipeline HBS 9-713-039 Humboldt Game Simulation Role Play (Harvard Law School Program on Negotiation) Sustainable Infrastructure Design Introduction to Sustainable Design Challenges in defining and reporting Sustainability Rating Systems Vertical Infrastructure Rating Systems: Introduction to LEED Case Study: Steven’s Institute New Gateway Academic Center Horizontal Infrastructure Rating Systems: Envision (Harvard Graduate School of Design) Case Studies: Selected Infrastructure Systems in North, Central and South America   participation: 10% assignments: 20% exams: 15% projects: 35%  attendance: 20% late_work: 20% of the total points will be deducted for assignments received 1-3 days late; assignments received more than 4 days late will receive 0 points. academic_integrity: Collaboration among students is strongly encouraged but with exception of group assignments, the work should be individual. accommodations: Stevens Institute of Technology is dedicated to providing appropriate accommodations to students with documented disabilities.

text:
Course: Mergers, Acquisitions and Other Corporate Restructuring (FIN 688)
    Semester: Fall 2023
    Credits: 
    Instructor: Dr. Suman Banerjee
    Description: Finance stands as the foundation of profit-driven enterprises. This core finance course equips students with skills and knowledge essential for diverse career paths, encompassing various investment types (especially in debt-involved firms), specialized investment situations, financial advisory roles, and finance research.
    Learning Outcomes: Assessing both theoretical and practical research within the realms of mergers and acquisitions, initial public offerings, corporate carve-outs, and spinoffs. Grasping the ramifications of corporate insolvency and restructuring on the wealth of stakeholders. Contrasting diverse models for making investment and divestiture choices amid uncertainty. Recognizing the legal dimensions of corporate investment and divestiture determinations, along with the impacts of legal risk on stakeholders’ wealth. Applying ethical frameworks to scrutinize organizational decision-making within the financial context.

Course: Introduction to Probability Theory (MA 540)
    Semester:  
    Credits: 3
    Instructor: Paul Schwartz
    Description: Introduction to Probability Theory aims to provide solid foundations of probability theory without requiring prior knowledge on measure theory.
    Learning Outcomes: Determine the conditional probability using Bayes’ theorem. Infer a suitable probability distribution function from a sufficient number of samples. Determine the expectation and (co)variance of random variables and random vectors, exploit the properties of the former, and apply the inequalities related to moments. Compare and relate the different modes of convergence. Analyze the convergence of random variables under certain conditions. Prove basic concentration inequalities and based on that explain the rationale behind certain applications/algorithms in data analytics. Compare the two discussed versions of the PageRank algorithms explaining how one addresses the flaws of the other and explain the mathematical concepts behind the PageRank Algorithm.
    Prerequisites: Advanced Calculus Introduction and Course Overview Probability Basics Conditional Probability and Independent Events Random Variables and Distributions (Part 1) Random Variables and Distributions (Part 2) Joint Probability Distributions and Independence Integration and the Properties of the Integral Expectation, Moments, and Covariance Characteristic Function, Moment Generating Function, and Conditional Expectation Convergence Types Limit Theorems Concentration Inequalities and Randomized Algorithms Stochastic Processes PageRank Algorithm and its Analysis Handbook of Probability by I. Florescu and C.A. Tudor. A First Course in Probability by S.M. Ross. Real and Complex Analysis by W. Rudin. Probability: Theory and Examples by R. Durrett. Probability and Statistics: The Science of Uncertainty by M.J. Evans and J.S. Rosenthal. course_title: Numerical Linear Algebra for Big Data
text:
Course: Numerical Linear Algebra for Big Data (MA 544)
    Semester:  
    Credits: 3
    Instructor: Upendra Prasad, PhD
    Description: This course will introduce foundational ideas as well as advanced techniques in linear algebra that are employed in the computational science of Big Data.
    Learning Outcomes: Apply foundational linear algebra concepts and understand several advanced linear algebra topics that are useful in handling high-dimensional data. Employ matrix/tensor representation of real-life data such as images, documents, and signals. Implement numerical linear algebra techniques for linear systems of equations, for solutions using various methods including matrix decomposition and iterative methods. Analyze various aspects of numerical approximation algorithms, including efficiency, accuracy, and stability. Apply matrix calculus and optimization for developing and implementing machine learning algorithms based on gradient descent and other methods. Evaluate and compare different algorithms in terms of complexity, cost of computation, and accuracy. Efficiently implement algorithms in Python. Apply advanced numerical linear algebra techniques for dimension reduction. Create matrix representations of graphs and networks. Create popularity ranking methods such as page ranking and social media standing based on network analysis. Perform clustering on data based on different metrics including similarity and associativity. Perform efficient transformation of data for various applications. Exploit sparseness in data and their matrix representation for economic and efficient operations.
    Prerequisites: Review of Basic Concepts - I Review of Basic Concepts - II Matrix Calculus Linear Systems and Iterative Methods Singular Value Decomposition (SVD) Principal Component Analysis (PCA) Least Square Problems (LSP) Nonnegative matrix factorization (NMF) Regression Analysis Graphs and Networks Sparse Matrices Randomized Numerical Linear Algebra - Part 1 Randomized Numerical Linear Algebra - Part 2 Matrix methods in data mining and pattern recognition by Elden, L.. Singular value decomposition in data-driven science and engineering: Machine learning, dynamical systems, and control by Brunton, S. & Kutz, J.. Introduction to linear algebra by Strang, G.. Matrix computations by Golub, G. H. & Van Loan, C. H.. Linear Algebra Review Slides from CS229-Stanford University by .  Mathematical Assignment Solve mathematical problems manually, proving simple mathematical results individually. Programming Assignment Use Python (Python, SciPy, ScikitLearn, etc.) to manipulate data, implement algorithms, and analyze performance of certain machine learning methods and linear algebra routines. Read and Discuss Participate in Canvas discussions forums in the form of comments and critiques geared toward answering a given set of questions on the topic. Quiz Canvas-based quizzes to motivate self-study and revision of topics. Live Session Participate in activities during Live Sessions (quizzes, breakout groups, and chat/discussion). Peer Review Peer review provided after each week’s live session. Students review each other’s responses to questions on the worksheets completed prior to the live session. Final Project The culmination of the course, where the students work on real-world problems on some moderately sized dataset in a group of two or three. Project proposals will be due by Module 7. Final Exam The final exam will be a cumulative exam on the mathematical concepts learned in the course.  participation: 10% assignments: 15% (Mathematical Assignments), 15% (Programming Assignments), 10% (Readings & Discussions), 10% (Quizzes), 10% (Live Session), 5% (Peer Review), 20% (Final Project), 15% (Final Exam) exams: 15% projects: 20% quizzes: 10% final: 15%  late_work: 10% of the total points (per day) will be deducted for assignments received 1-6 days late; assignments received more than 1 week late will receive 0 points. academic_integrity: Undergraduate Honor System applies to all undergraduate students in coursework and Honor Board proceedings. accommodations: Stevens Institute of Technology is dedicated to providing appropriate accommodations to students with documented disabilities.

Course: Optimization for Data Science (MA 576)
    Semester: Spring 2022
    Credits: 3 credits
    Instructor: Pedro Vilanova-Guerra
    Description: The objective of this course is to introduce the students to the theory and methods of optimization used in data science.
    Learning Outcomes: Use subgradients of convex functions and stochastic subgradients both for the purpose of theoretical analysis as well as in numerical methods. Use Lagrange duality in numerical methods and in decomposition approaches. Apply subgradient calculus to calculate subgradients of the dual functions applying Fenchel-Moreau theorem, Rockafellar-Moreau theorem and other results. Apply the first order necessary conditions of optimality for problems with differentiable and non-differentiable functions including the verification of appropriate constraint qualification conditions. Verify the optimality of points by the first- and second-order sufficient optimality conditions. Apply the basic steps of the numerical methods listed in the syllabus; be aware of their convergence assumptions, advantages and disadvantages; choose an appropriate numerical method for a given problem. Apply the fundamental decomposition and distribution approaches to create tailored distributed methods for particular applied problems. They will be aware of the applicability and convergence properties of the methods. Use stochastic approximation and randomized techniques; identify when these techniques are needed and how to apply them. Formulate a sample-based optimization problem and be aware of the necessary probabilistic guarantees for its solution.
    Prerequisites: Undergraduate knowledge of multivariate calculus linear algebra probability Optimization problems in data science (e.g., matrix completion, SVM, risk minimization, clustering) Properties of convex sets, separation and representation Convex functions Subgradient calculus Optimality conditions Lagrange duality Application to classification problems Gradient descent methods Newton’s method Choice of stepsizes Condition number Rate of convergence Conjugate gradient method Preconditioning Momentum acceleration techniques CG without gradients Midterm exam Subgradient methods for unconstrained optimization Subgradient methods with projection Basic dual method Cutting plane methods Regularization Proximal point and bundle method Application to ridge regression Penalty methods Application of subgradients and cutting-plane techniques to constrained problems Augmented Lagrangian Decomposition approaches for large problems ADMM ASM ADAL SLIN Sample average approximation Risk minimization Overfitting Bias and asymptotics Stochastic subgradient methods Basic version Averaging of direction Finite-difference methods Stochastic methods for constrained optimization Algorithmic improvements (e.g., Adam, AdaGrad) Variance reduction techniques Kernel smoothing (time permitting) Introduction to Stochastic Search and Optimization: Estimation, Simulation, and Control by James C. Spall. Nonlinear Optimization by Andrzej Ruszczynski. Lectures on stochastic programming: modeling and theory by Alexander Shapiro, Darinka Dentcheva, Andrzej Ruszczyński.     Credits: 3
    Instructor: Hadi Safari Katesari
    Description: The course will provide a basic introduction to modern time series analysis from both a theoretical and applied point of view.
    Learning Outcomes: Summarize and diagram time series data in statistical format. Apply stationary (ARMA) and nonstationary (ARIMA) time series models. Apply model specification and diagnostic for stationary and nonstationary times series models. Compute parameter estimation for time series models via statistical methods such as maximum likelihood. Predict the values for time series at future time points and interpret the results. Apply statistical techniques into seasonal time series (SARMA) modeling. Identify well-known time series models such as ARCH and GARCH. Apply spectral analysis, nonlinear models, and threshold models. Apply multivariate time series analysis.

    Instructor: Charles Cohn
    Description: This course provides an in-depth treatment of how to transfer the latest solar thermal and photovoltaic technologies available to real world applications.
    Learning Outcomes: Determine azimuth and altitude angles of the sun by calculation or using a sun chart. Identify module tilt angle and orientation that provides maximum energy production. Identify the different types of PV Modules, thermal collectors, system components and materials used in the systems and determine their appropriate applications. Calculate the heat loads of buildings and analyze hot water loads. Compare different types of passive/active thermal systems and their advantages and disadvantages. Identify data required and size/design PV and passive/active Thermal Systems. Calculate PV System performance using the online PVWatts tool. Identify the economic and non-economic benefits of the solar systems. Perform energy audits of residential and commercial buildings and identify cost effective opportunities for energy savings.
    Prerequisites: ME/MT-518 Course Review the Principles of Solar Radiation Heating Load Calculations Pressure Drop in Ducts and Piping Performance Analysis of Passively Heated Buildings Determining Active Solar System Thermal Performance Solar Photovoltaic Systems PV System Components Solar Powered Water Pumping Solar Desalination Solar Domestic Hot Water (DHW) Installation Balancing Conservation and Solar Computer Software Available for Solar System Performance Calculations Solar Energy Economics Special Topic – Energy Audits of Buildings Principles of Solar Engineering by D. Yogi Goswami. Electricity from Sunlight, an Introduction to Photovoltaics by Paul A. Lynn.  Weekly homework assigned on Mondays, due the following Monday by 12:00am EST. Class project reflecting real life consulting tasks, starting after Lecture #3.  assignments: 30% exams: 70% final: 40%  late_work: 20% of the total points will be deducted for assignments received 1-6 days late; assignments received more than 1 week late will receive 0 points. academic_integrity: Students must adhere to the Stevens Honor System and submit a pledge with all work. accommodations: Students with documented disabilities can receive accommodations through the Office of Disability Services.

Course: POWER PLANT ENGINEERING (ME510WS)
    Semester: Fall 2024
    Credits: 
    Instructor: H. Hadim
    Description: 
    Learning Outcomes: Demonstrate understanding of the energy resources and energy conversion methods available for the production of electric power. Analyze the performance of steam power plants, including superheat, reheat, regeneration, and irreversibilities. Analyze the performance of gas turbines with reheat and regeneration, and the performance of combined cycle and cogeneration power plants. Demonstrate understanding of the principles of steam generators. Analyze fuels and combustion systems. Explain the basic principles of thermal-fission and fast-breeder nuclear power plants, such as pressurized-water, boiling-water, and heavy-water reactors. Demonstrate understanding of power generation from renewable sources: solar, wind, geothermal, ocean thermal. Demonstrate understanding of the principles and potential of direct-electric power conversion systems, such as fuel-cell and solar photovoltaic units. Demonstrate understanding of the environmental impact of electric power production on air quality, climate change, water, and land.
    Prerequisites: Introduction Vapor Power Cycles Gas-Turbine Cycles Combined Cycles and Cogeneration Power Plant Design Mid-term Exam Fossil Fuel Steam Generators Fuels and Combustion Principles of Nuclear Energy and Nuclear Power Plants Renewable Power: Geothermal, Solar, Wind & Ocean Thermal Environmental Aspects of Power Generation Project Final Reports due Powerplant Technology by M.M. El-Wakil.   assignments: 35% exams: 30% projects: 35%  late_work: No late submission will be accepted. academic_integrity: Students must adhere to the Stevens Honor System.

Course: Introduction to Nuclear Engineering (ME 513WS)
    Semester: Spring 2024
    Credits: 
    Instructor: H. Hadim
    Description: This course is designed to provide students with a broad perspective of nuclear engineering and an introduction to fundamentals and applications of nuclear science and technology.
    Learning Outcomes: Demonstrate an understanding of the fundamental concepts and principles of nuclear engineering and its applications. Demonstrate an introductory knowledge of current and future nuclear power systems. Describe processes and applications that make use of the energy released from the nucleus, using both analytical and descriptive methods. Demonstrate an understanding of nuclear reactions, nuclear radiation and nuclear reactor heat generation. Demonstrate an understanding of neutron transport behavior. Demonstrate an understanding of a nuclear steam supply system, nuclear safety and the nuclear fuel cycle. Demonstrate an understanding of radiation protection and perform shielding calculations for simple reactor systems. Demonstrate a general understanding of nuclear power plant systems, licensing, design, operation & maintenance, safety and security. Perform a general design of a nuclear power plant including performance, economic, environmental, safety and reliability, and other considerations.
    Prerequisites: Introduction to Nuclear Engineering Atomic and Nuclear Physics Atomic and Nuclear Physics Interaction of Radiation with Matter Interaction of Radiation with Matter Nuclear Reactors and Nuclear Power Heat Removal from Nuclear Reactors Heat Removal from Nuclear Reactors Mid-Term Exam Radiation Protection and Shielding Reactor Licensing, Safety, and the Environment Reactor Licensing, Safety, and the Environment Special Topics: Regulations, Waste management Introduction to Nuclear Engineering by J.R. Lamarsch and A.J. Baratta.  Homework assigned weekly. No late submission will be accepted. Semester Project - apply methods and concepts learned in the course.  assignments: 35% exams: 30% projects: 35%  late_work: No late submission will be accepted. academic_integrity: Students must uphold the Stevens Honor System.

Course: Introduction to CAD (ME554)
    Semester: Fall 2024
    Credits: 
    Instructor: Chan Yu
    Description: Designs of modern products and processes are very complex, and complex designs rely heavily on computer-aided technologies. This course introduces the fundamentals of CAD and its application in design and manufacturing practices.
    Learning Outcomes: understand the fundamentals of CAD/CAM systems including the principles and practice of computer-aided solid modeling and its applications to manufacturing. understand the functionality of computer-aided tools including CAD/CAM/CAE. make an appropriate selection of CAD functionality to use as tools in the product design process. use parametric modeling techniques to reflect engineering requirements. design a part or assembly of parts using Computer-Aided Design software like Creo Parametric. sketch and design parts in CAD using features (e.g., extrude, revolve, sweep, blend, etc.) run a static finite element analysis and design optimization using CAD Simulation tools.
    Prerequisites: Introduction to CAD/CAM Introduction to Creo Parametrics Computer Aided Geometric Modeling Creo Basic Features Curves, Surface, and Solid Creo Feature (Extrusion) Feature Based Modeling Creo Feature (Revolve) Knowledge-Based Engineering (Parametric Modeling) Creo Engineering Drawings Platform Technologies (standardization, modularization, platforms) Creo Assemblies Computer Aided Reverse Engineering Creo Feature (Sweep & Blend) Midterm Exam Computer Aided Machine Design Creo Advanced Assembly & Drawing Computer Aided Engineering (CAE) Creo Feature (Patterns) Finite Element Modeling and Analysis Creo Simulate Computer Aided Manufacturing (CAM) Creo CAM Digital Manufacturing Creo Generative Design – Topology optimization Direct and Additive Manufacturing Creo Additive Manufacturing Design for Sustainability Creo Relations and Family Tables Review Peer review Computer Aided Design and Manufacturing by Zhuming Bi and Xiaoqin Wang. Designing with Creo Parametric 7.0 by Michael Rider. No more than 3 excuses are accepted. academic_integrity: Enrollment into the undergraduate class of Stevens Institute of Technology signifies a student's commitment to the Honor System. Course: Optimization Principles in Mechanical Engineering (ME564)
    Semester: Summer 2024
    Credits: 
    Instructor: Chan Yu
    Description: This course introduces traditional numerical optimization techniques that can be used to solve a wide variety of engineering optimization problems in the area of mechanical design and manufacturing.
    Learning Outcomes: formulate mechanical engineering design as an engineering optimization problem select the appropriate numerical techniques and software tools to solve the engineering optimization problem solve the optimization problem using Excel Solver and Matlab Optimization Toolbox optimize the design using Solidworks design study and topology optimization tool
    Prerequisites: Introduction to Engineering Optimization Analytical Technique & Graphical Optimization KKT Optimality Conditions Linear Programming - Simplex Method Single Variable Optimization Techniques Unconstrained Optimization: Direct Search Methods Unconstrained Optimization: First Order Gradient-based search methods Unconstrained Optimization: Second Order Gradient-based search methods Constrained Optimization: Gradient-based search methods Structural Design Optimization Heuristic / Stochastic Optimization Genetic Algorithms Particle Swarm Optimization Introduction to Optimum Design by Jasbir Arora. Applied Optimization with MATLAB Programming by P. Venkataraman.  Numerical problems Problems solving using Excel solver and Matlab Redesign using Solidworks design study Redesign using Solidworks topology tool Term project will be assigned to each student. Details of the project can be found in the project guide.  assignments: 30% projects: 50% final: 20%  late_work: Late assignments will not be accepted, except for medical reasons or prior approval by the instructor. academic_integrity: Generative AI Technologies: You may use AI programs e.g. ChatGPT to help generate ideas and brainstorm. However, you should note that the material generated by these programs may be inaccurate, incomplete, or otherwise problematic. Beware that use may also stifle your own independent thinking and creativity. You may not submit any work generated by an AI program as your own. accommodations: Stevens Institute of Technology is dedicated to providing appropriate accommodations to students with documented disabilities.

Course: Introduction to Robotics (ME 598)
    Semester: Fall 2024
    Credits: 
    Instructor: Mishah Uzziél Salman, Ph. D.
    Description: This course introduces students to a breadth of foundational topics relevant to robotic manipulators and mobile robots.
    Learning Outcomes: Apply mathematical foundations relevant for describing the geometry, motion, and behavior of robotic manipulators and wheeled mobile robots. Utilize mathematical methods for robot capability analysis and operation. Use software to perform analyses, generate programming code, and generate simulations for various robotic devices.
    Prerequisites: Knowledge of differential equations and matrix analysis strongly recommended Familiarity with fundamentals of computer coding and MATLAB recommended Introduction & Course Overview Manipulator Basics, Rot. & Trans. Manipulator Kinematics Velocity Kinematics Path & Trajectory Planning Control of Manipulators Actuators & Sensors Image Processing Virtual Lab 2 Mobile Robot Kinematics Virtual Lab 3 (Thanksgiving Week) Localization, Path Planning & Nav. Robot Modeling and Control by Spong, Hutchinson, Vidyasagar. Autonomous Mobile Robots by Siegwart, Nourbakhsh, Scaramuzza. Introduction to Robotics: Mechanics and Control by Craig.  Student Intro Introduction assignment for students. Problem Sets Five problem sets consisting of textbook-style example problems. Quizzes Quizzes administered during class times. Virtual Labs Three group assignments requiring various tasks and analysis. Final Project Group assignment with elaborate objectives and solution-freedom. Lab Participation Surveys Surveys to assess group participation.  participation: 10% assignments: 10% projects: 20% quizzes: 30%  attendance: Attendance during live, synchronous course meetings will factor into the class participation portion of term grades. Students receive one 'free' session they may miss without any grading impact. late_work: Unless agreed upon with the professor in advance, assignments received late may incur a 50% penalty. Late submissions will generally not be accepted after solutions are posted. academic_integrity: Students must adhere to the Stevens Honor System and the Graduate Student Code of Academic Integrity. accommodations: Students with documented disabilities must communicate with the professor to coordinate accommodations.

Course: Wearable Robotics and Sensors (ME-655 (BME-656))
    Semester: Fall 2024
    Credits: 
    Instructor: Damiano Zanotto, Ph.D.
    Description: The goal of this course is to provide students with an understanding of advanced methods used in the design and control of wearable robots and in the analysis of human motion through wearable sensors.
    Learning Outcomes: Identify kinematic and kinetic variables to quantitatively describe patterns of human locomotion. Systematically derive the conditions of kinematic compatibility between the human body and a wearable mechanism. Compare state-of-the-art actuator technology suitable for safe physical human-robot interaction (pHRI). Derive conditions of coupled stability for impedance controllers. Identify the most appropriate assistive or rehabilitation controller for a given application and implement/test the controller in simulation. Discuss state-of-the-art wearable sensing technology and related methods for human motion analysis and activity recognition. Apply supervised learning techniques to real-life data collected with wearable sensors, to infer and quantify the wearer’s motion.
    Prerequisites: ME-598 - Introduction to Robotics Course Overview, Review of Introduction to Robotics Topics Relevant to Wearable Robotics Review of Modern Control Topics & Feedback Linearization Virtual Lab Experience I – Simulating the Dynamic Behavior of a Robotic System Using Simulink Biomechanics of Human Locomotion Virtual Lab Experience II – Optical Motion Capture System Robotic Exoskeletons I: Ergonomic designs Robotic Exoskeletons II: Actuators in Wearable Robotics (SEA, VST, PMA) Robotic Exoskeletons III: Low-Level Control Student Flash Presentations Robotic Exoskeletons IV: Mid-Level Control Linear Estimation (Kalman Filter) Robotic Exoskeletons V: Fuzzy-based, Oscillator-based and EMG-based Control Virtual Lab Experience III – Overview of Simulation Lab Assignment Robotic Exoskeletons VI: Machine Learning Control Virtual Lab Experience IV – Introduction to OpenSim Robotic Manipulation in Medical Applications (Guest Lecture by Prof. Long Wang) Wearable Sensors I – Filters/Fusion Algorithms Wearable Sensors II – Supervised Learning for Activity Classification Overview of Lead Instructor’s research, Course Wrap-Up Wearable Robots: Biomechatronic Exoskeletons by J. L. Pons. Biomechanics and motor control of human movement by Winter, D.A.. Neurorehabilitation Technology by David J. Reinkensmeyer, Laura Marchal-Crespo, Volker Dietz. Springer handbook of robotics by Siciliano, Bruno, and Oussama Khatib. Control Systems Engineering by Norman S. Nise. Introduction to robotics: mechanics and control by Craig J.J..  P/F Problems Pass-fail homework assignments resembling real-world design and control problems. Student Presentation Select one paper from a given list and present its main contributions. Simulation Lab Develop dynamic simulations of human-robot coupled systems and cooperative controllers. Review Paper Literature review summarizing a minimum of 3 recent archival publications.  assignments: 30% projects: 30%  late_work: Assignments must be completed and submitted on or before specified due date. academic_integrity: Academic dishonesty will not be tolerated in any form. accommodations: Stevens Institute of Technology is dedicated to providing appropriate accommodations to students with documented disabilities.

Course: Autonomous Navigation for Mobile Robots (ME-656)
    Semester: Spring 2024
    Credits: 
    Instructor: Prof. Brendan Englot
    Description: Mobile robot geometry, kinematics, and dynamics. Control and estimation for autonomous vehicles. Motion planning, including discrete and continuous methods, and sampling-based planning. Simultaneous localization and mapping, including active SLAM and autonomous exploration with occupancy grids. Markov decision processes and partially observable Markov decision processes with application to mobile robots; planning under uncertainty. Introduction to supervised learning and reinforcement learning, including deep learning. Applications of machine learning to autonomous navigation.
    Learning Outcomes: Apply the techniques of control system design and state estimation design to mobile robotic systems Model the disturbances that contribute uncertainty to mobile robotic systems Use computer simulation as a tool for predicting the performance of a mobile robot and parameterizing a suitable navigation solution Analyze the robotics research literature to understand contemporary issues of your interest in mobile robot navigation Evaluate modeling assumptions and algorithms to solve localization, mapping, and planning problems
    Prerequisites: ME-598, Introduction to Robotics Course Overview Challenges of Robust Autonomy Control Systems for Mobile Robots State Estimation, Observation, and Kalman Filters Simultaneous Localization and Mapping (SLAM) – Part 1 Classic Papers in Mobile Robotics - Student Presentations Part 1 Classic Papers in Mobile Robotics - Student Presentations Part 2 Simultaneous Localization and Mapping (SLAM) – Part 2 Motion Planning Simulation Lab 2 Planning Under Uncertainty Robotics & Machine Learning – Part 1: Overview of M.L.; Robotics Applications Office Hours during Lecture time to discuss Sim Lab 2 Robotics & Machine Learning – Part 2: PhD Student Guest Lecture Literature Review Report Turn-In Autonomous Mobile Robots by Siegwart, Nourbakhsh, Scaramuzza. Principles of Robot Motion by Choset, Lynch, Hutchinson, Kantor, Burgard, Kavraki, and Thrun. Probabilistic Robotics by Sebastian Thrun, Wolfram Burgard, Dieter Fox. Planning Algorithms by Steven M. LaValle.  Presentation Assignment Release & Discussion SimLab 1 Release & Discussion SimLab 2 Release & Discussion Literature Review Assignment Release and Discussion  projects: 25% each for Student Presentation Assignment, Simulation Lab 1, Simulation Lab 2, Literature Review Paper  attendance: Student participation in our weekly synchronous Zoom lectures is highly encouraged. late_work: Assignments will receive a 10% penalty within the first week that they are submitted late, which will increase by 10% for each week thereafter. academic_integrity: All Stevens graduate students promise to be fully truthful and avoid dishonesty, fraud, misrepresentation, and deceit of any type in relation to their academic work. accommodations: Stevens Institute of Technology is dedicated to providing appropriate accommodations to students with documented disabilities.

Course: Leader Development (MGT 612-WN)
    Semester: Summer 2024
    Credits: 3.0
    Instructor: Kalim Rayburn
    Description: This course develops your leading and influencing capabilities.
    Learning Outcomes: Critique your leadership strengths and identify opportunities to develop personal/professional areas for growth. Engage in the processes of personal leader development. Distinguish among key theories and principles used to study leaders and leadership and apply these theories and principles to real-world situations. Utilize key skills and competencies to lead, influence, and build relationships.

Course: Managerial Judgment and Decision Making (MGT 635-WN)
    Semester: Summer 2024
    Credits: 3
    Instructor: Michele Lewski
    Description: The objective of this course is to help students understand how decisions are made, why they are often less than optimal, and how decision-making can be improved.
    Learning Outcomes: Evaluate past decisions and explore why decision-making can be challenging Assess decision-making from a psychological, statistical, and rational model perspective Analyze the limits of rational thinking – biases, emotions, and uncertainty and how to overcome them Apply strategies to enable better decision making Apply principles of negotiation
    Prerequisites: Introduction and Course Overview Overview of Decision Making Bounded Awareness in Decision Making Decision Making in Uncertainty Columbia Case & Bounded Ethicality: Part 1 Problem Definition and Framing Effects Motivational and Emotional Impacts on Decisions – Bounded Ethicality: Part 2 Group Decision Making: Everest Leading Through Uncertainty Crisis Decision Making Negotiating Decisions Improvement in Decision Making Decision Forum – Part 2 Judgement in Managerial Decision Making by M. H. Bazerman and D. A. Moore.  Prepare a report that summarizes the events leading up to the Columbia and Tenerife disasters, with a brief compare-and-contrast analysis. Prepare a brief power point presentation (5 – 7 slides max.) to be presented to and distributed to the rest of the class. Work in small teams to identify, address, and improve a major decision that is upcoming or was faced in the past. Consider your past decisions, approaches and practices along with the materials presented throughout the semester.  participation: 15% assignments: 20% projects: 20%  attendance: Attendance is expected at ALL Live sessions as many of the sessions will involve active discussion and participation. late_work: Late submissions will be considered in some, and not all cases.     Credits: 3
    Instructor: Mansoor Basha
    Description: The study of marketing principles from the conceptual, analytical, and managerial points of view.
    Learning Outcomes: Apply a number of strategic and tactical marketing concepts such as Segmenting, Targeting, and Positioning (STP) to real-world situations. Assess a variety of market problems and opportunities. Create a credible integrated marketing plan. Course: Entrepreneurship (MGT 663)
    Semester: Summer 2023
    Credits: 
    Instructor: Frank Gallucci
    Description: This course is offered for students who seek to understand the process of creating and developing business opportunities within organizations or who want to initiate and create their own venture.
    Learning Outcomes: Contrast small business ideas from entrepreneurial business ideas by applying basic economic principles. Assess entrepreneurial business opportunities with a set of comprehensive evaluation criteria entirely and differentiate between attractive and non-attractive business opportunities. Apply frameworks to transform an entrepreneurial business idea into a complete and viable venture idea. Communicate entrepreneurial business ideas by applying basic principles of business pitch development.
    Prerequisites: Introduction to Entrepreneurship Invention vs. Innovation Defining Entrepreneurship Entrepreneurship and its economic importance Entrepreneurship in the light of economic theory Entrepreneurial Opportunity Components Technology, Market, Business Model Innovations Uncertainty Entrepreneurial Profit Customer Discovery & Value Proposition Components Design Process Sources of Entrepreneurial Opportunity Sources of business opportunities Competition Analysis & Entrepreneurial Opportunity Evaluation Porter’s 5 Forces Model Evaluation criteria for entrepreneurial opportunities Opportunity Checklist Business Model Canvas & Patterns Components Business Model Patterns Lean Startup Methodology Customer verification, pricing Integrating the Value Proposition into the Business Model Canvas The Role of the Entrepreneur & IP Building the Entrepreneurial Team Analyzing the specific situations of entrepreneurs Different forms of IP Startup Financials Sources of finance Cash flow & NPV projections Financial Analysis Venture Growth Strategies Market activities Technological innovation activities Management activities Exit strategies Business Plan Analysis & Business Idea Pitch Business plan components Business plan evaluation Pitch Essentials Pitch Checklist Social Entrepreneurship Two conflicting logics Cases of social ventures Venture Idea Pitch Presentation & Discussion of Business plan issues Patterns of Entrepreneurship Management by Jack M. Kaplan; Jack McGourty. Value Proposition Design: How to Create Products and Services Customers Want by Alexander Osterwalder, Yves Pigneur, Gregory Bernarda, Alan Smith, Trish Papadakos.  Class Attendance Recorded for every lecture Class Participation Participation in weekly class discussions via online discussion boards on Canvas.
