course_title: Future of Work: Implications for Leadership & Organizations
text:
Course: Future of Work: Implications for Leadership & Organizations (MGT 675)
    Semester: Fall 2024
    Credits: 1.5
    Instructor: Denise Rotatori
    Description: This is a 1.5-credit course in the Stevens Institute of Technology's online Masters in Business Administration (OMBA) program, designed for scholar practitioners interested in the future of work (FoW) during this current period in history, often referred to as the fourth Industrial Revolution (4IR).
    Learning Outcomes: Gain a common understanding of the disruptive technologies at play in the 4IR. Review illustrative ways in which these emerging technologies are impacting various sectors of the economy. Examine similarities and differences between the 4IR and prior periods of transformative change. Examine different philosophical orientations toward what these technologies mean for the future of work. Review the way in which these broader trends have impacted professional practice. Explore the role that leaders can play in stewarding effective workforce transitions within their organizations. Review the ethical implications and challenges due to the rise of cognitive technologies.
    Prerequisites: Introduction and Course Overview Implications of the 4IR on the Future of Work (FoW) and Workforce Harnessing the Power of Disruptive, Emerging Technologies Opportunities for Organizational Leadership in the 4IR Key Takeaways for Additional Academic Research and Professional Practice on the 4IR The Second Machine Age: Work, Progress, and Prosperity in a Time of Brilliant Technologies by McAfee, Andrew and Brynjolfsson, Erik. Work Disrupted by Schwartz, Jeff & Riss, Susan. A World Without Work by Susskind, Daniel.  Prepare a 500-word Canvas post in response to the class and readings. Respond with 500-word Canvas post to a cohort member’s post (additional responses welcome, at least 1 reply required). 5-page paper, double spaced, APA citation standards, due prior to in-person immersive experience. In small teams, prepare group presentation during the immersion weekend. Prepare a 500-word Canvas post in response to the class and readings. Prepare a 500-word Canvas post in response to the class and readings. 5-page paper, double spaced, APA citation standards, based on literature and immersion experience.  participation: 15% assignments: 25% final: 40%  attendance: Attendance for live learning events will count toward final grades. Each live learning session will comprise 3% of the course grade. late_work: Assignments submitted up to 48 hours late will automatically receive one letter grade reduction, assignments submitted thereafter will not receive credit. academic_integrity: All Stevens graduate students promise to be fully truthful and avoid dishonesty, fraud, misrepresentation, and deceit of any type in relation to their academic work. accommodations: Stevens Institute of Technology is dedicated to providing appropriate accommodations to students with documented disabilities.

Course: Strategic Management (MGT699)
    Semester: Fall 2024
    Credits: 
    Instructor: Ann Murphy, Ph.D.
    Description: An interdisciplinary course which examines the elements of, and the framework for, developing and implementing organizational strategy and policy in competitive environments.
    Learning Outcomes: Formulate strategic recommendations to help firms create and sustain competitive advantage. Analyze an organization’s internal and external environments using a variety of quantitative and qualitative tools and techniques. Discriminate between tactical and strategic approaches to problems, and be able to elevate the approach to be more strategic when necessary. Generate strategic alternatives and solutions. Leverage technology in both the approach to strategic management analyses as well as in the strategic management solutions for organizations. Defend strategic analyses and recommendations in individual and group reports and presentations.
    Prerequisites: FIN500 FIN515 Overview of Strategic Management Value Creation Mission, Vision & Values Situational Assessment: External Environment part 1 'PESTEL' Situational Assessment: External Environment part 2 Industry Analysis Situational Assessment: Internal Environment Goal Setting & Corporate Strategy Formulation Business/Competitive Strategy Formulation, Part I Business/Competitive Strategy Formulation, Part II Strategy Execution Strategic Leadership & Corporate Governance Corporate Social Responsibility, ESG & Ethics Bringing it altogether Strategic management: From theory to practice by Amazon, A. and Ward, A..  News Report Presentation Each student will sign up to be a news reporter for one live session during the semester. The report should be a short presentation (1 slide, 5 minutes) that highlights an example of a topic discussed during that module. Midterm Case Memo You will write a 6-page memo that analyzes a published case using the concepts from the course, and provides recommendations based on that analysis. Mini Team Assignments Throughout the course, you will work in teams and will be given small assignments to prepare in advance of live sessions. Final Case Presentation At the end of the course, your team will perform a comprehensive strategic analysis of a company and summarize your findings and recommendations in a final presentation. Team Member Evaluation At the end of the course, your teammates will evaluate your contributions to the team’s assignments, and you will do the same for them.  participation: 15% assignments: 10% exams: 25% projects: 20% quizzes: 10% final: 10%  attendance: It is expected that you make an effort to attend live sessions and come ready to participate. Zoom automatically records attendance. Full credit for attendance will only be given to those who stay logged on for the entire live session. late_work: Assignments received late will be given the following late penalties: 1-3 days late: 5-point deduction; 4-7 days late: 10-point deduction; 8+ days late: half credit. 2 weeks from the original due date is the limit for late submissions. academic_integrity: All Stevens graduate students promise to be fully truthful and avoid dishonesty, fraud, misrepresentation, and deceit of any type in relation to their academic work. accommodations: Stevens Institute of Technology is dedicated to providing appropriate accommodations to students with documented disabilities.

Course: Econometrics (MGT 700)
    Semester: Fall 2024
    Credits: 
    Instructor: Pallavi Pal
    Description: Econometrics, literally “economic measurement,” is a branch of economics that attempts to quantify theoretical relationships.
    Learning Outcomes: Understand the difference between an economic model and an econometric model Define the linear regression model based on the classical linear regression Perform ordinary least squares (OLS) estimation. Use hypothesis testing and confidence interval construction for the population parameters based on the finite sample properties of OLS estimators. Understand extensions to the linear regression model including heteroskedasticity and autocorrelation. Employ time-series regression. Understand the basic panel data methods. Be proficient in the empirical estimation of a model using statistical software.
    Prerequisites: BT221 Statistics QF200 or Equivalent Foundations of Econometrics and Introduction to Linear Regression Basics of Data Visualization in Econometrics Understanding Simple Linear Regression Exploring Multiple Linear Regression: Part 1 Exploring Multiple Linear Regression: Part 2 OLS Methodology: Hypothesis Testing and Restrictions Advanced Inference Techniques using OLS Challenges in Regression: Dealing with Heteroskedasticity and Autocorrelation First Presentation Session Midterm Examination Introduction to Binary Outcome Models Panel Data Analysis: Fixed and Random Effects Models Advanced Topics in Panel Data: Instrumental Variables Introductory Econometrics: A modern approach by Jeffrey M. Wooldridge.  Submission 0 Submission 1 Presentation 1 and submission 2  participation: 10% assignments: 30% exams: 30% projects: 30%  attendance: Participation is highly encouraged in class. I will try to rotate questions across all students so that everyone gets a chance to participate. academic_integrity: Students in graduate courses (600 level) are bound by the Graduate Student Code of Academic Integrity. accommodations: Stevens Institute of Technology is dedicated to providing appropriate accommodations to students with documented disabilities.

Course: Economics for Managers (EMT506)
    Semester: Summer 2024
    Credits: 
    Instructor: Joelle Saad-Lessler
    Description: This course introduces managers to the essence of business economics – the theories, concepts and ideas that form the economist’s tool kit encompassing both the microeconomic and macroeconomic environments.
    Learning Outcomes: Use supply and demand to explain various economic phenomena and principles. Explain the measurement and importance of GDP, inflation, unemployment, money, and trade. Explain the economic meaning of price, elasticity, and production costs. Describe the cause and effect of changes in all of these variables. Draw and analyze cost and revenue curves that maximize profit. Discuss differences and critically analyze the pros and cons of different market structures, including competitive, monopolistic and oligopolistic markets. Read and explain the content of economic materials from a secondary source (such as the Wall Street Journal, New York Times, etc.) Relate economic concepts to these real-world events and critically evaluate the impact of economic policy.
    Prerequisites: Demand and Supply Consumer and producer surplus Price and quantity controls Elasticity Taxes Producer choice Costs of production. Supply in perfect competition Price and quantity decisions in Monopoly Oligopoly and Monopolistic Competition Game theory Introduction to Macroeconomics GDP Inflation Unemployment Growth and the Loanable Funds Market Aggregate Demand and Aggregate Supply Fiscal Policies The Money Market The FED Monetary policies The Phillips curve Economics by .  End of chapter problems from the textbook.  assignments: 30% exams: 60% quizzes: 10% final: 30%  attendance: Attendance will not be taken, but students are expected to attend weekly and turn on their camera. late_work: Late homework submissions will be assessed a 10% penalty. academic_integrity: All students must adhere to the Graduate Student Code of Academic Integrity. accommodations: Students with documented disabilities can receive accommodations through the Office of Disability Services.

Course: Leading Across Projects (Management 619)
    Semester: Spring 2024
    Credits: 
    Instructor: Pete Dominick, Ph.D.
    Description: This course explores executive leadership skills required in complex organizations.
    Learning Outcomes: Making executive-level decisions in complex environments Shaping the environment and driving change Identifying and developing talent among team leaders and members
    Prerequisites: Mgt. 612: Leader Development Orientation and Course Overview Authentic Leadership: Self-awareness, Your Values and Ethical Conduct Adaptive Leadership Decision making and Program Failures Learning From Failure Leadership & Improvisation Recognizing and applying principles of influence Storytelling and Story Gathering Coaching Dynamics & Personal Development Planning Selecting talent Leading within and across teams Shaping program and organizational culture Leading change Overall Course Wrap –up  You will prepare and submit self-reflective journals that document what you are learning and experiencing in the course. course_title: Project Portfolio Management and the Program Management Office
text:
Course: Project Portfolio Management and the Program Management Office (MGT 613)
    Semester: Fall 2024
    Credits: 
    Instructor: Dr. Alan C. Maltz, P.E.
    Description: MGT 613 covers the concepts of Project Portfolio Management (PPM) and the Program Management Office (PMO). The course discusses a framework of PPM, including portfolio planning, monitoring and control. Tools and techniques of PPM are discussed. The course also addresses different types of PMO including their functions. Steps for implementing PPM and PMO in an organization are also covered. Case studies are used throughout the course to help students gain a better understanding of the material.
    Learning Outcomes: Introduce a strategic, system perspective of organizational project management. Discuss a framework of project portfolio management. Practice applying tools and techniques used in project portfolio management. Discuss different types and functions of program management offices.
    Prerequisites: MGT 609 MGT 610 ORIENTATION WEEK Introduction to PPM and the PMO Fundamentals of PPM Project evaluation and prioritization Maximizing Value Portfolio risks and balancing The link to Strategy Strategic Alignment PPM Framework Monitoring and Controlling the PPM framework PPM Implementation Fundamentals of the PMO Functions of PMO 1: Consulting, knowledge, or standard center Functions of PMO 2: Business integration and governance, and resource and career center Implementation of PPM and the PMO Review of Current Research, Course Conclusions The Standard for Portfolio Management by Project Management Institute. Organizational Project Portfolio Management: a Practitioner’s Guide by Prasad Kodukula. Case Studies for Project, Program, and Organizational Project Management by Dragan Z. Milosevic, Peerasit Patanakul, and Sabin Srivannaboon. The Program Management Office: Establishing, managing, and growing the value of a PMO by Craig J. Letavec.  Weekly assignments are team-based presentations of class exercises. Those assignments are not graded but feedbacks are provided for continuously developing and integrating the assignments into the midterm and final presentations and reports.  participation: 20% exams: 40% projects: 40%  academic_integrity: Cheating during in-class tests or take-home examinations or homework is illegal and immoral. Consequences of academic impropriety are severe, ranging from receiving an 'F' in a course to expulsion.

Course: Data Integration for Business Intelligence (MIS 636)
    Semester: Fall 2023
    Credits: 3.0
    Instructor: Chris Asakiewicz, PhD
    Description: This course will focus on the design, management, and use of data warehouse (DW) and business intelligence (BI) systems.
    Learning Outcomes: Perform the functions of a data architect in industry as evidenced through lab assignments and the final project. Assess business information needs and apply appropriate data-oriented technology solutions. Design a business intelligence system. Apply the data warehouse life cycle in the development of a business intelligence system. Develop conceptual data models. Leverage commercial tools (Erwin, MongoDB, and Alteryx) for business intelligence and data integration. Build dashboards and visualizations for business intelligence.
    Prerequisites: Students must satisfy the requirements for enrollment in either the BI&A or MIS master’s degree programs. Introduction to Business Intelligence and Data-Driven Decision-Making Databases and Data Modeling Data Warehousing -- Business and Technical Needs Data Warehousing -- Technical Architecture Dimensional Modeling Application of Data Modeling Data Staging and Extract, Transform, and Load (ETL) Data Integration Business Intelligence Applications Visual Analytics Big Data and Analytics Business Analytics Trends and Directions Team Presentations Business Intelligence, Analytics, and Data Science: A Managerial Perspective by Sharda, R., Delen, D., Turban, E.. Business Intelligence Guidebook: From Data Integration to Analytics by Sherman, R.. Course: Integrating IS Technologies (MIS 730)
    Semester: Fall 2024
    Credits: 
    Instructor: Jeffrey Nickerson
    Description: This course focuses on ways of designing and integrating information systems architectures.
    Learning Outcomes: By the end of this course, students will be able to formulate a series of plausible alternative designs for integrating technologies. Students will know the different components of IS architectures, how they work, and how they integrate with each other. Students will improve their ability to communicate about design in group and presentation settings.
    Prerequisites: Introduction Overview of the course Design space Evaluation space Generative AI Discussion of first problem First Problem Presentations 1 Crit Bios/Photos in Canvas First Problem Presentations 2 Crit Prototyping discussion Second Problem Presentation 1 Crit Second Problem Presentation 2 Crit Mechanisms of Integration Third Problem Presentation 1 Crit Third Problem Presentation 2 Crit Memory and Disk Moore's law How storage speeds drive design decisions Midterm Review of midterm Discussion of final projects Ideas for projects Working session on final projects Come prepared to start working with your team Guest lecturer Machine Learning, AI, Autonomous Tools Trends in AI: LLMs, Diffusion models, Multi-modal systems, alignment Designing the Metaverse Augmented and Virtual Reality Gaming platforms and the ongoing design of the metaverse Final Presentations 1 Final Presentations 2  Group grades as one grade for all members, adjusted based on individual contributions. Course: Data Analytics and Machine Learning (MIS-637)
    Semester: Summer 2024
    Credits: 3
    Instructor: Dr. Foad Mahdavi Pajouh
    Description: This course will focus on Data Mining & Knowledge Discovery Algorithms and their applications in solving real world business and operation problems.
    Learning Outcomes: Formulate the objectives of Knowledge Discovery using Data Analytics and Machine Learning algorithms, and identify profound questions to be answered. Identify relevant data and corresponding databases, data warehouses, and data sources from which Knowledge can be extracted. Preprocess the data (Clean, Integrate, and Transform). Determine proper algorithms, discovery models, and technologies to use for Knowledge Discovery. Execute and discover patterns and dependencies to make predictions. Extract and apply Nuggets of knowledge to make intelligent scientific, business, and operations decisions. Present and document results. Input the extracted knowledge to the next iterative step.
    Prerequisites: Students are expected to be familiar with calculus, elementary probability & statistics. Course Introduction Introduction to Data Mining and Knowledge Discovery Understanding and Preparing Data I Understanding and Preparing Data II Supervised Learning: k-Nearest Neighbor Algorithm I Supervised Learning: k-Nearest Neighbor Algorithm II Supervised Learning: Decision Trees I Supervised Learning: Decision Trees II Supervised Learning: Neural Networks I Supervised Learning: Neural Networks II Unsupervised Learning: k-Mean Clustering Algorithm Project Review and Discussion Case Presentations and Discussion Discovering Knowledge in Data: An introduction to Data Mining by .  Homework To help reinforce the material covered in the module, a homework exercise will be assigned to you each week. Case Study Reports and Presentations These are team assignments. You will be required to read a case study and apply the principles learned throughout the course. Final Team Project There is a practical final project that provides an opportunity to apply and demonstrate knowledge you acquired throughout the course. Peer Evaluations Required submission with each team assignment. These support collaboration and will be used to adjust grades based on individual contribution.  participation: 10% assignments: 30% exams: 40% projects: 20%  late_work: Late homework or final project submissions will be subject to a 20% deduction. academic_integrity: All Stevens graduate students promise to be fully truthful and avoid dishonesty, fraud, misrepresentation, and deceit of any type in relation to their academic work. accommodations: Stevens Institute of Technology is dedicated to providing appropriate accommodations to students with documented disabilities.

Course: Digital Innovation (MIS 699A)
    Semester: Fall 2024
    Credits: 
    Instructor: Dr. Cherif Amirat
    Description: This course focuses on how organizations can effectively and efficiently assess trends and emerging technologies in data and knowledge management, information networks, and analyzing and developing application systems.
    Learning Outcomes: Students will learn and, in teams, research and create presentations on emerging technologies, new business models and methodologies. Students will be able to separate the “hype” of new technology from the underlying business opportunities and technical challenges. Students will be assigned a current emerging technology to research and provide a “technology briefing” presentation for the class. Students will be able to identify the requirements for a specific information system and express these requirements in a form usable by Information Technology professionals. Students will be able to apply the concepts learned during the lectures and cases in their final project. Students will be able to determine the advantages and disadvantages of different technologies, information systems and business structures for a specific application.
    Prerequisites: MIS710 MIS630 FIN615 Introduction Overview history of change and disruptive technologies "Objects you View Through Your Windshield May Appear Further than they Actual Are" How do I spot emerging Trends? When is the right time to invest in new technology? What is your appetite for taking risks? Which firms/products should I examine? "Crossing the Chasm" Who & Which organizations are willing to try new technologies? Breakthrough thinking - applied science versus the 'aha' moment? Can you formalize the innovation process and effective use of new technologies/ways of doing business? How much money? How much risk? Should you cross the Chasm? Standards Standards wars - who sets the standards? How are standards set? – What is the process? “DeJure” (Formal) vs DeFacto Standards? Historical/Current Standards Wars (AC/DC, Bar Code, Monolithic (control all) systems vs Heterogeneous (linked) systems) Examination of standards behind some key emerging technologies "It’s a Generational thing" What is the organization of the future going to look like? How will that effect how new technologies are brought into the organization? The psyche of the generations (ex. Millennials vs others) Handling change "Dave, I’m afraid I can’t do that" The introduction of automated technology? Reliability and “Trust” in automation technology? The age of Semantic Technologies and Thinking machines Autonomous transportation (Airtrain, Google cars) Robots/Drones IBM Watson If it doesn’t work, is there a Plan B? or Plan C? Planning for the unexpected? Scenario Planning Big bang versus incremental strategy Social Networks and Network Data Micro-blogging and its application "The whole is greater than the sum of its parts" How do Information Systems support Business Processes? CRM, SCM, and PLM Processes Workflow Systems Structured Data / Unstructured Data & Big Data Case examples – Amazon, Otis Elevator, Zipcar "Everything makes SENSE!!!" Sensory systems – measuring the world around us. Sight, sound, motion, heat, touch, taste, smell Our multi-instrumented devices – our phones Wearable Technology "Opinions DO count!" Or "I Know What You Did Last Summer." How have Information Systems been used in political campaigns? Data Mining E-mail marketing Micro-targeting Social networking/media Business Analytics "Look Ma, no hands." The mobile worker/consumer? Wireless technologies impact systems. Mobile systems and infrastructure The BYOD challenges. Software development models Requirements Engineering Software re-use "I’ll have my phone give your PC a call and make all the arrangements" - and - "Now you see it – now you don’t!" How did the Age of Machines and machine to machine communications change the world? The Internet of Things Scada Systems & RFID and NFC GPS / Micro GPS Automobile technology Authentication Technologies How will a virtual world change our understanding of value – opportunities out of Thin Air. Artificial Currencies (Bitcoin) Avatars Compressed design, prototyping and production cycle. 3D Printing Virtualization of Servers and Desktops Information Systems: A Manager's Guide to Harnessing Technology by John Gallager. The Back of the Napkin (Expanded Edition): Solving Problems and Selling Ideas with Pictures by Dan Roam. Why Not?: How to Use Everyday Ingenuity to Solve Problems Big And Small by Barry Nalebuff and Ian Ayres.  Weekly Submission of a “Heard it on the Grapevine” article Assignments will be set up to ensure students are completing reading assignments Individual Emerging Technology Presentation Midterm (online during lecture time) Final Project – Group Project – Developing a new product or service using one or more expansive emerging technology  participation: 10% assignments: 20% exams: 10% projects: 60%  attendance: Attendance is required. Final Group Presentations require attendance. late_work: In fairness to others, late work will be penalized 10% per day overdue. academic_integrity: Enrollment into the undergraduate class of Stevens signifies a student’s commitment to the Honor System.

Course: IT Strategy (MIS 760)
    Semester: Fall 2024
    Credits: 
    Instructor: Katia Meggiorin
    Description: This course addresses the strategic responsibilities and roles of the CIO and IT managers.
    Learning Outcomes: Develop an IT strategy that aligns with the business Understand the current issues facing the IT organization and have tools to address them Apply how IT can deliver value Explain the changing role of the CIO Understand how IT can develop a partnership with the business Discuss some of the ways technology is being used to transform organizations Understand how IT can drive business improvement and a competitive advantage
    Prerequisites: Introduction and overview of course Business Strategy IT as a service Alignment strategies Role of the CIO Business Models Discussion of the IT topic/issue From technology to value Developing IT strategy for business value Creating and evolving a Digital Strategy Business Improvement and Competitive Advantage Business Improvement and Competitive Advantage Innovation with IT Developing thought leaders in IT Business Intelligence Moving to an API economy Business Intelligence Preparing for Artificial intelligence Managing emerging technologies IT STRATEGY & INNOVATION by James McKeen and Heather Smith.  Individual Case Study: One case study will be graded. Analysis will include critical review of the management decisions presented in the respective case, followed by the student’s recommendations to management. Each question should be addressed separately. Case study write-ups should be 3-5 pages in length. IT Topic presentation: This is a team assignment. One of the current IT topics will be chosen from a list that will be provided. The team is to do a thorough analysis, using as many of the tools and techniques discussed in class. You will prepare a presentation and give in class. Current 2-article presentation: This is a team assignment. Your team will find 2 current articles (must be within the last 6 months) that are relevant to this course. You will be assigned a week in which you will discuss the articles you have found. Your team will lead a discussion in class on the articles. IT Strategy presentation: This is a team assignment. Students will develop an IT Strategy for the firm they work for or a selected firm of their choosing in a 45-minute presentation, using the note field for providing details. The presentation will be given in class. Participation: Class participation and sharing of real life experiences are part of the learning process in this class. Attendance is a part of class participation, but it is not sufficient to get participation points.  participation: 10% assignments: 60% projects: 40%  attendance: Students are expected to attend all classes and be active in lecture discussions. academic_integrity: Any plagiarism or other form of cheating will be dealt with under relevant Stevens policies. accommodations: Stevens Institute of Technology is dedicated to providing appropriate accommodations to students with documented disabilities.

It provides a comprehensive treatise on the science and technology of solar energy, its collection and the design principles that need to be understood for its effective use in a variety of installations and uses.

text:
Course: Financial Decision Making (FIN 515 WS/WS1)
    Semester: Fall 2024
    Credits: 
    Instructor: Narcyz Roztocki, Ph.D.
    Description: FIN 515 provides the requisite survey of financial accounting, managerial accounting, and corporate finance topics.
    Learning Outcomes: Describe and contrast the information needs of external stakeholders and management. Apply steps in the financial reporting process and prepare financial statements. Gain an understanding of some commonly used financial statement metrics. Characterize, calculate, and assign costs with particular emphasis on manufacturing overhead costs. Prepare budgets using provided estimates and assumptions, compare actual results to budgeted expectations, and evaluate differences and performance. Explain and apply the time value of money concepts. Understand the valuation of stocks. Evaluate capital investments.
    Prerequisites: Accounting in Action: Basic of Financial Accounting Accounting Cycle: Recording and Adjusting Process Accounting Cycle Continued: Financial Statements and Closing Process Accounting for Merchandising Operations Financial Analysis: The Big Picture Managerial Accounting Midterm exam Job Order Costing Cost - Volume - Profit Analysis Incremental analysis Budgetary Planning and Control Time Value of Money and Discounted Cash Flows Stock Evaluation Financial and Managerial Accounting by Jerry J. Weygandt, Paul D. Kimmel, Jill E. Mitchell.   assignments: 30% exams: 70% final: 40%  late_work: No late submission is permitted for the assignments (Homework & Online Exams). academic_integrity: All outside assistance must be acknowledged. Any student who violates this code shall be subject to discipline. accommodations: Stevens Institute of Technology is dedicated to providing appropriate accommodations to students with documented disabilities.

text:
Course: Financial Decision Making (FIN 615 WS)
    Semester: Fall 2021
    Credits: 
    Instructor: Narcyz Roztocki, Ph.D.
    Description: This course introduces students to the principles of accounting and finance.
    Learning Outcomes: Apply accounting and financial principles supplemented with financial ratio analysis techniques to analyze the operational results of a firm over time and relative to competitive and market benchmarks. Analyze cost behavior and evaluate operational outcomes reported by different costing systems. Use accounting information and apply financial principles to make better investment and resource allocation decisions. Appreciate how operating efficiency, investment effectiveness and financial structure increase firm value and maximize investment returns to shareholders.

Course: Operations Management (MGT 657)
    Semester: Summer 2024
    Credits: 
    Instructor: Foad Mahdavi Pajouh, Ph.D.
    Description: Introduces the student to the concepts and techniques used by organizations to support their fundamental task of producing goods and services.
    Learning Outcomes: Explain how the production and operations function is managed and how it interfaces with other key business functions. Prescribe the tools and analytical techniques used by managers to improve operations and to aid decision-making. Facilitate the various demand forecasting techniques. Incorporate the concepts of quality management into the enterprise’s operations. Explain the core concepts of supply chain management, the goals of a supply chain, the impact of supply chain decisions on the success of a company, and key decision areas. Develop models for making network design decisions and use optimization methods for facility location and network design decisions. Cultivate the details of capacity planning, facility planning, locating, layout and design. Handle the facets of production planning, scheduling and inventory control systems.
    Prerequisites: Spring Commencement – No Classes Course Overview and Introduction Introduction to Operations Management Operations and Productivity Juneteenth – No Classes Supply Chain Management Inventory Management Case Presentations and Discussions Forecasting (Exam 1) Managing Quality and SPC (Part 1) Managing Quality and SPC (Part 2) Facility location and network design Case Presentations and Discussions (Exam 2) Operations Management: Sustainability and Supply Chain Management by Heizer, J., Render, B., & Munson, C..     Semester: Summer 2024

    Instructor: Professor Marc Bernhardt
    Description: This course explores the economic theory of regulation in general, and the US and international regulatory environments that govern the pharmaceutical, medical device and biotechnology industries.

    Description: This course introduces students to the Software Engineering principles and practices of DevOps.

Course: Real-Time and Embedded Systems (CPE555WS)
    Semester: Fall 2023
    Credits: 
    Instructor: Dr. Jack Winters
    Description: This course is a survey of many topics of interest to designers of real-time and embedded systems.
    Learning Outcomes: Define what real-time embedded systems are, and give examples of each Describe the difference between hard- and soft-real-time systems Describe the size, weight, and power requirements that constrain embedded systems Describe the differences between Harvard and Von Neumann machines and their benefits Describe how pipelining is used to improve processor performance List the types of memory devices used in embedded systems, and explain the benefits and drawbacks of each Describe the principles behind caching and the associated performance improvements Describe what purposes interrupts and timers serve in embedded system designs Determine what hardware interfaces should be used for different devices commonly used in modern embedded systems Describe common issues related to concurrent/multi-threaded programming and how to resolve them Develop simple multi-threaded applications in C Use common features of real-time embedded operating systems and develop simple applications in FreeRTOS Describe various scheduling algorithms used in real-time systems and analyze the feasibility of different schedules
    Prerequisites: Orientation Introduction to Real-Time and Embedded Systems Embedded Processor Architecture Memory and Caching C Programming for Embedded Systems Interrupts & Timers Communication Busses & I/O Hardware/Software Partitioning Midterm Exam Real-Time Operating Systems Multitasking RTOS Programming Aperiodic Scheduling Periodic Scheduling Presentations Final Exam Embedded Systems: A Contemporary Design Tool by James K. Peckol. Computer Organization and Design, The Hardware Software Interface: ARM Edition by David Patterson and John L. Hennessy. Modern Embedded Computing by Peter Barry and Patrick Crowley. Hard Real-Time Computing Systems: Predictable Scheduling Algorithms and Applications by George Buttazzo.     Credits:

    Description: An introductory course for machine learning theory, algorithms, and applications.

    Description: The course will review different topics related to risk modeling and management, specifically in line with Financial Risk Manager (FRM) Parts I and II (mainly Part I).

The Essentials of Risk Management by Michel Crouhy, Dan Galai, and Robert Mark. Risk Management and Simulation by Aparna Gupta. Practical Methods of Financial Engineering and Risk Management: Tools for Modern Financial Professionals by Rupak Chatterjee.  There will be three long assignments over the semester. course_title: Future of Work: Implications for Leadership Communications
text:
Course: Future of Work: Implications for Leadership Communications (MGT 676)
    Semester: Fall 2024
    Credits: 1.5
    Instructor: Steven Gogel
    Description: This is a 1.5-credit course in the Stevens Institute of Technology's online Masters in Business Administration (OMBA) program, designed for scholar practitioners interested in the future of work (FoW) during this current period in history, often referred to as the fourth Industrial Revolution (4IR).
    Learning Outcomes: Analyze the importance of different communication strategies for effective leadership. Apply communication strategies (including active listening) to foster collaboration and engagement in the context of evolving digital platforms. Create strategies to navigate multi-perspective conversations, thinking critically on topics such as digital transformation and sustainability, to drive innovative solutions. Design a framework for future-focused feedback for fostering quality improvement, collaboration, and innovation in the 4th Industrial Revolution.
    Prerequisites: MGT 675 (Future of Work: Implications for Leadership & Organizations) MGT 612 (Leader Development) Building the Case for Durable skills in the Future of Work Going Beyond Active Listening in a Tech-Driven Era: Deep Listening, Active Learning, and the Power of Observation Sustaining Engagement with Two-way Communication Critical Thinking and Navigating Complex Discussions Optimizing conversations regarding User requirements in a Dynamic 4th IR Landscape Fueling Inspired Innovation through Multidisciplinary Thinking Future-Focused Feedback for Collaboration Moving Ahead  Pre-immersion Individual Written Assignment (personal professional statement) Discussion board 1 post Discussion board 2 post Discussion board 3 post Submission of draft notes on research proposal Responses to peer discussion board posts 1, 2, and 3 Team presentation during virtual session Written feedback on other team's presentation Mini-research brief/proposal Post-immersion personal written statement  participation: 15% assignments: 65% projects: 20%  attendance: Attendance for live learning events will count toward final grades. Course: Data Management (MIS631)
    Semester: Fall 2023
    Credits: 2 credits
    Instructor: Elizabeth Gomez
    Description: This 2-credit course focuses on data and database management, with an emphasis on modeling and design, and their application to business decision making. The course provides a conceptual understanding of both organizational and technical issues associated with data. The central theme concerns data modeling and databases. We examine organizational approaches to managing and integrating data. Among the topics included are normalization, entity-relationship modeling, relational database design, SQL, and data definition language (DDL). Discussed are specific applications such as strategic data management, master data management, and physical database design. The course concludes with a brief overview of Decision Support Systems, data warehousing and business intelligence, NoSQL databases (e.g., MongoDB) and cloud computing. The course includes several case studies and modeling and design projects.
    Learning Outcomes: Understand the role of data in the competitiveness and strategy of organizations Design relational databases in normalized form Build SQL queries Develop and critique entity-relationship (ER) data models Elucidate advanced data modeling issues e.g., temporal data modeling, meta-data, etc. Identify and analyze data quality in a business context Develop and evaluate strategic data plans; e.g., Master data management plan, enterprise data strategy & models Understand the growing importance and issues associated with data warehousing, business intelligence and analytics, and big data.
    Prerequisites: Students must satisfy the requirement for enrollment in either the BI&A or MIS master’s degree programs. Introduction to MIS631 Introduction to Data Management Functions Factors Affecting Data Management Functions Tutorial on Database and Database Design Organizations and Data Research paper presentations & discussion Query Languages – SQL Tutorial on Abstraction and ER Data Modeling Extended ER; Generalizing Data Model Patterns Information Modeling Information Modeling – Advance Modeling Contracts and Formal Methods Discuss Key Semester Learnings Data and Database Administration Functions Physical Database Design Strategic Data Modeling Application of Data Modeling and Database Design to a business area Data Warehouse, Business Intelligence, and Big Data Row & Column data storage MapReduce exercise No Class for Thanksgiving Recess based on circumstances Cloud Computing and Data Architectures NoSQL: document, key-value, column-wide, graph Major Data Project Presentation (Team) Database Concepts by .  Review and comment on several assigned readings from the research and professional literature and modeling exercises. Developing a business case. Required SQL Module: https://www.sololearn.com/Course/SQL/  Individual assignment focused on technology. References and all sources used (articles, texts, Web sites, etc.) must be provided in standard format. Develop a functional database demonstrated at the conclusion of the course. Includes business problem analysis, identification of database requirements, data modeling, and creation of the database. Assessment based on contributions to in-class discussions throughout the semester.  participation: 10% assignments: 10% exams: 15% (Mid-term), 15% (Information Modeling Exam) projects: 40% (Team Database Project)

course_title: Good Manufacturing Practice in Pharmaceutical Facilities Design
text:
Course: Good Manufacturing Practice in Pharmaceutical Facilities Design (PME 535WS)
    Semester: Fall 2021
    Credits: 
    Instructor: Leonid Shnayder
    Description: Become familiar with current Good Manufacturing Practice (GMP) compliance in the design of pharmaceutical and biopharmaceutical facilities.
    Learning Outcomes: Describe the special requirements related to manufacturing of drugs and how they must affect the architectural, mechanical and process design of manufacturing facilities. Assess process, mechanical and architectural design of pharmaceutical manufacturing facilities and evaluate their compliance with Good Manufacturing Practices. Select and recommend process equipment and components, architectural finishes, environmental parameters and other design features appropriate for manufacturing of pharmaceuticals. Effectively communicate results of their assignments and research about pharmaceutical manufacturing in oral presentations and in written reports.
    Prerequisites: Introduction to the Course and Overview of cGMP Process Engineering Architectural Design Concepts Design of the API and Biotech Manufacturing Facilities Design of the OSD and other Non-Sterile Manufacturing Facilities Design of Facilities for Sterile Products Manufacturing Midterm exam HVAC Design for Pharma Facilities Industrial Health & Safety Design of Process Utilities Design of the Automation and Control Systems Facility Design, Construction and Qualification Design of the Warehousing and Packaging Facilities Good Design Practices For GMP Pharmaceutical Facilities by T.Jacobs, A.Signore.  Weekly homework assignments due on Thursday of each week; participation in online discussion by commenting on at least one posting by classmates due by Sunday. Term paper/project details to be posted during the course.  participation: 240 points assignments: 120 points exams: 120 points projects: 80 points quizzes: 120 points final: 120 points  attendance: Not applicable late_work: Grades for late submissions will be reduced unless you ask for an extension in advance with a good reason. academic_integrity: All students must adhere to the Graduate Student Code of Academic Integrity. accommodations: Stevens Institute of Technology provides appropriate accommodations to students with documented disabilities.

Course: Validation in Life Sciences Manufacturing (PME540WS1)
    Semester: Spring 2023
    Credits: 
    Instructor: Leonid Shnayder
    Description: Validation of a pharmaceutical manufacturing process is an essential requirement with respect to compliance with Good Manufacturing Practices (GMP).
    Learning Outcomes: Describe the validation concepts and apply them for validation of pharmaceutical manufacturing facilities, equipment and processes. Assess process and mechanical design of pharmaceutical manufacturing facilities and evaluate their compliance with the process needs, with Good Manufacturing Practices and other applicable regulations. Select critical quality attributes of pharmaceutical products and critical process parameters that need to be controlled in order to produce quality products. Effectively communicate results of their assignments and research about pharmaceutical manufacturing in oral presentations and in written reports.
    Prerequisites: FDA Regulations Drug Development Process Introduction to Validation Process Design Facility, Utility and Equipment Qualification Process Performance Qualification Continued Process Verification Validation of Analytical Methods Midterm Exam Cleaning Validation Validation of Sterilization Qualification of Environmental Control Systems Computerized Systems Validation Medical Devices and Packaging Validation VMP, Change Control and SUPAC Term Papers due How to Validate a Pharmaceutical Process (Expertise in Pharmaceutical Process Technology) by Steven Ostrove.  Weekly homework submission due on Thursday of each week; participation in online discussion by commenting on at least one posting by classmates due by Sunday. text:
Course: Statistical Methods in Life Science Industries (PME602WS)
    Semester: Spring 2024
    Credits: 
    Instructor: Leonid Shnayder
    Description: This course is focused on the application of statistics and statistical reasoning in pharmaceutical and life science manufacturing.
    Learning Outcomes: demonstrate familiarity with common statistical concepts analyze life science manufacturing processes using the above mentioned concepts and statistical software assess laboratory and in-process measurement methods and determine their precision and accuracy develop and evaluate sampling plans for process validation and quality control implement statistical process control methods in life science manufacturing utilize design of experiments in process development and validation

Tests of Hypothesis for A Single Sample Tests of Hypothesis for Two Samples Correlation and Regression. Midterm exam. Course: Manufacturing of Biopharmaceutical Products (PME-626WS)
    Semester: Summer 2022
    Credits: 
    Instructor: Leonid Shnayder
    Description: This course is focused on topics related to the technology, design and operations of modern biopharmaceutical facilities.
    Learning Outcomes: demonstrate familiarity with technologies, unit operations and GMP requirements for the manufacturing of biopharmaceutical products analyze and develop manufacturing processes for most common biopharmaceuticals formulate facility and process equipment requirements for manufacturing of biopharmaceuticals develop and implement Standard Operating Procedures and other GMP documentation for various manufacturing and support operations
    Prerequisites: PME530 ME530 CHE530 Introduction to biopharmaceutical manufacturing. Fermentation and cell culture – process technology, equipment and controls. Harvest and clarification of biological products. Centrifugation, microfiltration, depth filtration. Filtration processes in protein purification. Ultrafiltration, diafiltration, viral clearance, sterilizing filtration. Chromatography systems in protein purification. Auxiliary process operations (media and buffer preparation, dispensing, storage). Midterm exam Design of Biopharmaceutical Facilities Equipment cleaning in modern biotech facilities (Clean-In-Place, Clean-Out of-Place). Sterilization of Equipment, Piping and Process Fluids (Steam-In-Place, Autoclave Sterilization, Biowaste Treatment) Simulation of Biopharmaceutical Processes Disposable Equipment Systems in Biopharmaceutical Manufacturing Facility Construction, Commissioning and Qualification. Term papers due. Manufacturing of Pharmaceutical Proteins: From Technology to Economy by Stefan Behme. Course: Fundamentals of Systems Engineering (SYS 625)
    Semester: Spring 2024
    Credits: 
    Instructor: 
    Description: The course introduces students to the principles and processes of systems engineering.
    Learning Outcomes: Understand the need for good systems engineering up front and throughout the life cycle of the system. Review and evaluate the various systems engineering models in use today. Differentiate between the operational need and the system solution to be implemented. Select from a wide range of system concepts as the first step in system design. Derive quantitative system requirements that best meet the functions and performance requirements of the system. Adopt a systems perspective when making decisions that affect performance or total ownership cost of the system.
    Prerequisites:  Applied Space Systems Engineering by . The Innovator’s Dilemma by .  Complete/update a student profile at the beginning of the course. Ensure that team assignments are posted on time to the correct discussion group when serving as team leader. Participate in the online discussion for each week. course_title: Wireless Networking: Architectures, Protocols, and Standards
text:
Course: Wireless Networking: Architectures, Protocols, and Standards (EE-582)
    Semester:  
    Credits: 
    Instructor: Prof. Yu-Dong Yao
    Description: This course addresses the fundamentals of wireless networking, including architectures, protocols, and standards. It describes concepts, technology and applications of wireless networking as used in current and next-generation wireless networks. It explains the engineering aspects of network functions and designs. Issues such as mobility management, wireless enterprise networks, GSM, network signaling, WAP, mobile IP, and 3/4/5G systems are covered.
    Learning Outcomes: Student will be able to understand the relevance of mathematical principles in wireless network designs. Student will be able to identify inputs and outputs in wireless networks. Student will be able to understand the key modules in wireless networks. Student will be able to understand the design principles and methods in wireless networks. Student will be able to develop ideas for presentation by clearly outlining crucial concepts. Student will be able to follow current professional literature in various media.
    Prerequisites: Introduction to Wireless Networking Wireless Transmission Fundamentals Wireless LAN Technologies Cellular Networks and Mobile IP Wireless Sensor Networks Ad hoc and Mesh Networks Wireless Network Security Mobile Device Management and Internet of Things (IoT) Wireless Network Performance and Optimization Cognitive Radio and Dynamic Spectrum Access Next-Generation Wireless Technologies Case Studies and Emerging Topics   assignments: 50% projects: 50%  academic_integrity: All Stevens graduate students promise to be fully truthful and avoid dishonesty, fraud, misrepresentation, and deceit of any type in relation to their academic work. A student’s submission of work for academic credit indicates that the work is the student's own. All outside assistance must be acknowledged. course_title: Introduction to Stochastic calculus for Finance
text:
Course: Introduction to Stochastic calculus for Finance (FE543)
    Semester: Fall 2023
    Credits: 
    Instructor: Prof Pape Ndiaye
    Description: This course is designed for advanced undergraduate students and masters students in Financial Engineering. The goal is to learn the stochastic calculus foundation on which Quantitative Finance is built upon.
    Learning Outcomes: Understand the concept of Non-arbitrage and its link to Risk-neutral Pricing Understand the basic concepts of Binomial Asset Pricing Model and its use for Risk-neutral pricing of derivatives Understand the concepts of Martingales and Markov processes Understand the basic properties of Random Walks, Brownian Motion, Stochastic Integral Develop continuous time models and value basic asset classes such as European options using Black and Scholes
    Prerequisites: Background in Calculus and Probability One Period BAPM Multiperiod Model and FPS Expectation in BAPM Martingales and Markov Stopping Times and Random Walks SSRW and BM Quadratic Variation and MP Midterm Reflection Prop. and Cont. Passage Times Stochastic Calculus Integrands Ito’s Formula Black-Scholes and Levy Change of Measure Stochastic Calculus for Finance vol I by Steven E. Shreve. Stochastic Calculus for Finance vol II by Steven E. Shreve. Introduction to Probability Models by Sheldon M. Ross. Probability and Random Processes by Geoffrey Grimmett and David Stirzaker. Stochastic Differential Equation by Bernt Oksendal. Introduction to the Mathematics of Financial Derivatives by Salih N Neftci.  Around 5 homework assignments throughout the semester.  participation: 5% assignments: 20% exams: 60% quizzes: 15% final: 35%  attendance: Attendance is mandatory. The class will be interactive. academic_integrity: Students must uphold the Stevens Honor System.

Course: Portfolio Theory and Applications (FE630)
    Semester: Fall 2023
    Credits: 
    Instructor: Prof Pape Ndiaye
    Description: This course is an introduction to quantitative portfolio theory, practice, optimization, and management. It addresses investor choice, market opportunities, and optimal portfolio selection. It examines security covariance and return models, performance analysis, and return attribution. It provides also an introduction to some basic methods for robust portfolio construction. The course will also include a computational component in which students will construct optimal portfolios, track their behavior, and analyze their performance.
    Learning Outcomes: Compute Absolute Risk Aversion (ARA), Certainty Equivalent of Risky (CER) of risky gamble and Risk-premiums Solve Optimal Decision Problems arising in Modern Portfolio Theory and implement the solution using a high level language such as R, Matlab or Python Design Markowitz efficient portfolios and use the One-fund Theorem and the Two-fund theorem to build efficient Portfolios with Target Return or Target Risk Use CAPM, APT and Factor Model to compute security Expected Returns and Risk and Covariance Apply Markowitz Allocation to design, implement and backtest Optimal Portfolios using historical price time series, analyze the sensitivity to various inputs, and manage Fixed Income portfolios
    Prerequisites: Background in Algebra, Optimization, Stochastic Calculus Comfortable with the material presented in FE 543 or FE610 (Stochastic Calculus for Financial Engineering) and FE620 (Pricing and Hedging) Some familiarity with Matlab and R, (and / or Python) Orientation & One Period Utility Course Introduction Course Overview Student Introduction and Initial Assessment First Motivating Examples One-Period Utility Analysis Absolute and Relative Risk Aversion Certainty Equivalent and Risk Premium Orientation & One Period Utility Course Introduction Course Overview Student Introduction and Initial Assessment First Motivating Examples One-Period Utility Analysis Absolute and Relative Risk Aversion Certainty Equivalent and Risk Premium Computational Tools, Algebra & Optimization for Portfolio Portfolio expected return and risk Portfolio weights Attainable regions of risk-return space Risk reduction and diversification Review of algebra for Portfolio and matrix calculus Convex and Nonlinear optimization basics Equality and Inequality Constraints KKT conditions and closed-form solution to Markowitz Allocation Computational Tools, Algebra & Optimization for Portfolio Portfolio expected return and risk Portfolio weights Attainable regions of risk-return space Risk reduction and diversification Review of algebra for Portfolio and matrix calculus Convex and Nonlinear optimization basics Equality and Inequality Constraints KKT conditions and closed-form solution to Markowitz Allocation The opportunity Set Mean-Variance Eﬃcient Frontiers CAPM, APT Multi-Factor Models Mean-variance Frontier Portfolios The Markowitz Eﬃcient Frontiers with and without Risk-free security One and two-fund theorems Market Price of Risk and Security Market Line CAPM, APT, Single index and Multi-Index models Pricing and Arbitrage opportunities The opportunity Set Mean-Variance Eﬃcient Frontiers CAPM, APT Multi-Factor Models Mean-variance Frontier Portfolios The Markowitz Eﬃcient Frontiers with and without Risk-free security One and two-fund theorems Market Price of Risk and Security Market Line CAPM, APT, Single index and Multi-Index models Pricing and Arbitrage opportunities Mid-semester Review Midterm Project Sensitivity to Inputs & Robust Allocation Models of uncertainties of Expected Returns and Risk Matrices Models of Robust Allocation Worst Case Optimization Matrix Calibration Black Litterman Allocation Portfolio Characteristics & Applications Portfolio Characteristics Active and Passive Portfolios Management Performance attribution Asset Versus Risk Allocation Portfolio construction to mitigate interest rate risk sensitivity Dynamic Portfolio Allocation Risk Sensitive Asset Allocation Maximum Principle HJB Equation Feedback using Riccati Equation Final review Course evaluation Presentation of Final Projects Modern Portfolio Theory by Francis and Kim. Active Portfolio Management by Grinold and Kahn. Essential mathematics for Market Risk Management by Hubert. Portfolio Optimization and Performance Analysis by Prigent.  Four to six homework assignments in which students will do theoretical analysis and write programs for portfolio management in both Matlab, R or Python. Students will form groups of three or less, and each group will be required to design, implement, backtest and run a comparative analysis of quantitative investment strategies according to modern portfolio management principles.  participation: 10% assignments: 20% exams: 20% projects: 35% quizzes: 15%  attendance: Attendance is mandatory. The class will be interactive. Students are required to participate and answer questions on the reading assignments. academic_integrity: Students must write and sign the pledge: 'I pledge my honor that I have abided by the Stevens Honor System.'

text:

    Semester: Fall 2024
    Credits:

    Description: The course prepares students to employ essential ideas and reasoning of applied statistics.
    Learning Outcomes: Understand and summarize complex data sets through graphs and numerical measures Calculate estimates of parameters using fundamental statistical methods Give measures of how good the estimators are by providing confidence intervals or approximate confidence intervals Apply statistical tests to experimental observations Estimate and calibrate parameters of mathematical models using real data Study relationships between two or more random variables Lay the foundation for a more advanced applied statistical course such as time series analysis, statistical learning, deep learning, and more.

course_title: Time Series with Applications to Finance
text:
Course: Time Series with Applications to Finance (FA-542)
    Semester: Fall 2024
    Credits: 
    Instructor: Dragos Bozdog
    Description: This course is designed for Master and Ph.D. graduate students and advanced undergraduates. The purpose is to learn applied statistical methodologies pertaining to time series.

Course: Foundations of Financial Data Science (FA-582)
    Semester: Fall 2023
    Credits: 
    Instructor: Dragos Bozdog
    Description: This course will provide an overview of issues and trends in data quality, data storage, data scrubbing, and data flows.
    Learning Outcomes: Have a working knowledge of the issues of data quality, data storage, data scrubbing, data flows, and their potential solutions. Understand and design various schemas needed for the representation of financial data. Tackle problems dealing with data management issues such as collection, warehousing, preprocessing and querying. Have a working understanding of all the databases available for them through the Hanlon lab. Understand the data science pipeline process including processing, analytical tools, and outlier analysis. Apply the newly acquired data management and database skills to analyze financial data from the capital markets, social media, and the financial services sector.
    Prerequisites: Introduction to Financial Data Science Data Science Process Sample Data Processing The Basic Data Types The Major Building Blocks: A Bird’s Eye View Introduction to R Case Study: Exploratory Data Analysis (NYC Real Estate) Financial Data Quality Issues and Data Scrubbing Data Preparation Feature Extraction and Portability Data Cleaning Data Reduction and Transformation Handling Missing Entries Handling Incorrect and Inconsistent Entries Scaling and Normalization Sampling for Static Data and Data Streams Dimensionality Reduction Intro Web page retrieval scrapping regular expression extraction basic statistical techniques to identify wrong data entries Case Study: Data and Web Technologies Linear Model Piecewise linear model Similarity and Distances Impact of High Dimensionality Generalized Minkovski Distance Match-Based Similarity Computation Impact of Data Distribution ISOMAP Impact of Local Data Distribution Similarity on Categorical Data Similarity on Mixed Quantitative and Categorical Data Text Similarity Measures Time Series Similarity Measures Classification Methods Tree-Based Methods Clustering Methods Financial Time Series Data Using Decision Tree to Trade Stock Building a Trading Strategy Handling Time-Dependent Data in R The Prediction Models Mining Text Data Document Preparation and Similarity Computation Specialized Clustering Methods for Text Probabilistic Algorithms Co-Clustering Topic Modeling Case Study: Using Statistics to Identify Spam Blockchain Cryptocurrencies Outlier Analysis (Extreme Values, Clustering Models, Distance-Based Models, Density-Based Models, Probabilistic Models, Information-Theoretical Models) Hadoop HDFS & MapReduce Hive Pig Data Classification: Algorithms and Applications by Charu C.     Description: The course aims to introduce the required techniques and fundamental knowledge in data science techniques. It helps students to be familiar with database and data analysis tools. Students will be able to manage data in database and solve financial problems using R program packages.
    Learning Outcomes: Use R to scrape, clean, and process data Use relational database to store data locally Manage database through R and get data from database using R Design efficient relational databases for different data sizes and different industry Use NoSQL (MongoDB) to store data Design efficient MongoDB databases
    Prerequisites: Intro to course working environment setup Basic R: Usage of Packages and functions Advanced R: functions and visualization SQL I: Intro to PostgreSQL SQL II: Table Join and Set Operation SQL III: Subquery and I/O SQL IV: Role Management and Function SQL V: Triggers and Backup/Restore SQL and R: PostgreSQL API and other APIs SQL VI: Explain SQL VII: Index and Summary MongoDB I: Intro to NoSQL and MongoDB Setup MongoDB II: Basic Query Syntax Database System Concepts by Avi Silberschatz. SQL QuickStart Guide: The Simplified Beginner’s Guide to Managing, Analyzing, and Manipulating Data With SQL by Walter Shields. MongoDB: The Definitive Guide: Powerful and Scalable Data Storage by Eoin Brazil.   assignments: 60% exams: 40%  late_work: No late assignment is allowed without permission from instructor. academic_integrity: All Stevens, graduate students promise to be fully truthful and avoid dishonesty, fraud, misrepresentation, and deceit of any type in relation to their academic work. A student’s submission of work for academic credit indicates that the work is the student’s own. All outside assistance must be acknowledged. Any student who violates this code or who knowingly assists another student in violating this code shall be subject to discipline. All graduate students are bound to the Graduate Student Code of Academic Integrity by enrollment in graduate coursework at Stevens.

Course: Advanced Derivatives (FE-680)
    Semester: Summer 2024
    Credits: 
    Instructor: Dragos Bozdog
    Description: This course will address the practical and theoretical issues for interest rate models, credit models, and hybrid instruments.
    Learning Outcomes: understanding and implementation of advanced interest rate derivatives models. ability to model single name credit derivatives. ability to model multi-name credit derivatives.
    Prerequisites: FE 620 – Pricing and Hedging Static curves: Construction of discount factors, zero coupon rates, forward rates. Pricing bonds and interest rates swaps. Bond price sensitivity to interest rates moves (duration, DV01, convexity). Bootstrapping Yield Curve. Interpolation Methods (Linear, Exponential, Cubic Spline, Nelson-Siegel Model). Interest Rate Derivatives (Bond Options). Interest Rate Derivatives (Caps and Floors, Swaptions). Convexity, Timing, Quanto Adjustment. Non-Standard Swaps (Compounding Swaps, Currency Swaps, CMS and SMT swaps, Differential Swaps). Interest Rate Derivatives: Models of the Short Rate. Equilibrium Models (Vasicek, CIR). No-Arbitrage Models (Ho-Lee, Hull-White One-Factor Model, Black-Derman-Toy Model, Black-Karasinski Model). Interest Rate Derivatives: Models of the Short Rate (Hull-White: Two-stage procedure for constructing trinomial trees, Vasicek Model: Recombining binomial tree procedure). Interest Rate Derivatives: (Hull-White Two-Factor Model, HJM Model, and BGM Model). Credit Risk: Default event and survival probabilities. Risk neutral and realized default probabilities. Forward default intensity curve. Estimating Default Probabilities using Bond Prices and Historical Data. Meton’s Model. CDS (CDS and Bond Yields, Valuation of Credit Default Swaps). Implied Hazard Rates from CDS spreads. Implied default curves. CDO (Cash and Synthetic CDO, Waterfall Mechanism, STCDO, Valuation of Tranches). Gaussian Latent Variable Model (CDO and Correlation, Multi-Name Latent Variable Model, Asset Correlation and Dependency, Conditional Hazard Rates, Portfolio Loss Distribution, Simulating Multi-Name Defaults). Modelling Default Times using Copulas (Default Times Dependencies, Measure of Dependency, Default and Survival Copula Functions: Gaussian, Student-t, Marshall-Olkin, Archimedean Copulas). Statistical Inference for Copulas (MLE, IFM, CML, Empirical). Interest Rate Models - Theory and Practice: With Smile, Inflation and Credit by Damiano Brigo. Modelling Single-name and Multi-name Credit Derivatives by Dominic O'Kane.   assignments: 60% final: 40%  academic_integrity: All Stevens, graduate students promise to be fully truthful and avoid dishonesty, fraud, misrepresentation, and deceit of any type in relation to their academic work. accommodations: Stevens Institute of Technology is dedicated to providing appropriate accommodations to students with documented disabilities.

Course: International Finance (FIN 648)
    Semester: Spring 2024
    Credits: 
    Instructor: Dr. Ying Wu
    Description: The course covers important topics in international financial management, including foreign exchange management.
    Learning Outcomes: Describe the principle of comparative advantage and absolute advantage. Describe the international monetary system and a variety of exchange rate systems in the world. Describe relationships between exchange rates and economic variables. Identify best practices for measuring and managing exchange rate risk. Synthesize and evaluate financing options for multinational corporation management. Gain a practical understanding of factors contributing to foreign exchange rate risks.
    Prerequisites: FIN 510 Financial Statement Analysis FIN 616 Managerial Economics FIN 638 Corporate Finance Syllabus & Intro The International Financial Environment: Introduction The Determination of Exchange Rate: World Trade The Determination of Exchange Rate: The Equilibrium Approach Case Study and Discussions The International Monetary System Case Study and Discussions Quiz 1 Parity Conditions in International Finance and Currency Forecasting Balance of Payments and Economic Linkage No class Spring Recess The Foreign Exchange Market Quiz 2 Currency Futures and Option Markets Swaps and Interest Rate Derivatives in the International Finance Markets Country Risk Analysis International Financing and National Capital Market Group Presentation Multinational Financial Management by Alan C Shapiro.  Case Study due on May 2nd, 2024. Group project involving building a case from scratch.  participation: 30% projects: 40% quizzes: 30%  attendance: Attendance will be taken into consideration in grading. late_work: Late submissions lose 10% for each day late. academic_integrity: All students must adhere to the Honor System. accommodations: Students with special testing needs or disabilities are encouraged to contact the instructor.

Course: Statistical Methods (MA 541)
    Semester: FALL 2024
    Credits: 3
    Instructor: Hong Do
    Description: This course offers an introduction to exploratory data analysis and the use of basic statistical tools.
    Learning Outcomes: Apply basic and classical statistical concepts, theories, methodologies, inferences, and models that are important in data science and machine learning. Demonstrate the complete data analyzing process commonly employed in academia and industry. Apply the required statistical skills to each stage of the data analysis procedure, including mathematical transformation of the scientific statement, data collection, data description, data preprocessing, model selection, output interpretation, conclusions, and decision-making. Compare the similarities and differences among various statistical models, estimation, and prediction methods as well as commonly used and advanced approaches to data analysis. Choose the appropriate statistical tools to understand and explore different types of data arising from engineering and sciences. Evaluate assumptions and restrictions made on classical statistical methodologies, and understand the importance of developing new technologies in machine learning and data science.
    Prerequisites: MA 540  Mathematical statistics and data analysis (with CD data sets) by Rice, J. A.. An introduction to statistical learning with applications in R by James, G., Witten, D., Hastie, T., & Tibshirani, R..  Homework Assigned weekly and due the following Tuesday by 11:59 pm. Unlimited attempts allowed before due time. Scan and upload work as a PDF. Quizzes Assigned weekly, 30 minutes long, due by 11:59 pm the following Monday. Two attempts allowed. Midterm Exams Two midterm exams conducted on Canvas over two weekend days. Course Project Group-based project applying major statistical methods to a real-life data set with a formal project report. Final Exam Final exam in the form of a project presentation.  participation: 10% assignments: 25% exams: 20% projects: 20% quizzes: 5% final: 20%  attendance: Attendance is mandatory for live sessions. late_work: 20% of the total points (per day) will be deducted for homework assignments received 1-5 days late; assignments received more than 5 days late will receive 0 points. Late quiz submissions will not be accepted. academic_integrity: Students must adhere to the Stevens Honor System and submit work with the pledge: 'I pledge my honor that I have abided by the Stevens Honor System.' accommodations: Stevens Institute of Technology provides accommodations for students with documented disabilities through the Office of Disability Services.

Course: Strategic Management (Mgt 699)
    Semester: Summer 2024
    Credits: 
    Instructor: David Stahl, Ph.D., MBA
    Description: This course presents models and ideas that can be used to improve decision-making in strategic management.
    Learning Outcomes: Acquire conceptual models and tools to dissect a firm. Diagnose problems and evaluate a firm’s long-term prospects. Propose changes in strategic direction. Identify viable initiatives that enhance a firm’s economic value. Refined ability to present evidence and conclusions.
    Prerequisites: Module 0 – Introduction to Course Overview of Strategic Management What is strategy? Origins of business strategy. Develop Mission & Vision, Business Case Analysis Evaluating and Formulating Strategies Case Analysis and Financial/Operational Benchmarking External Analysis Analysis of the business landscape, the industry, its life cycle stage, the competitive environment, the strategic groups within an industry, competitor analysis, Porter’s Five Forces, and PEST analysis. External Analysis - 2 Perform Internal Analysis and SWOT Benchmarking Analysis of the company’s opportunities for growth and increased profit and threats to existing businesses. Functional Level Strategy Efficiency, Innovation, Quality, and Customer Responsiveness Business Level Strategy Differentiation and Cost Leadership The Delta Model Evaluating Competitors Moves Analyzing competitors. Anticipating competitors’ counter moves. Corporate Level Strategy What strategies are employed in multi-business companies? Industry Transformation What happens when industries change because of new technology, regulations, industry ecosystem or changes in customers’ tastes and needs? Organizational Structure and Strategy Strategy implementation. How does organizational structure affect strategy? Global Strategy Final Presentations Strategy and the Business Landscape by Pankaj Ghemawat.  Journal Article Reviews - Summarize key points of assigned journal articles and post the review on Canvas. HBS Cases - Teams will prepare case analyses of 5 Harvard Business Cases. Strategy Business Case - Project defining a change in strategic direction and accompanying strategic initiatives for a selected company.  participation: 10% assignments: 35% exams: 35% projects: 45% final: 35%  attendance: Attendance at online sessions is recommended but not mandatory. Students unable to attend should view the recording. late_work: Late assignments will be accepted only if discussed with the instructor in advance. Course: Strategic Perspectives on Project Management (MGT610-WZ)
    Semester: Fall 2024
    Credits: 
    Instructor: Thomas Lechler, Ph.D.
    Description: This course will introduce students to the Stevens’ concept of Project Value Management.
    Learning Outcomes: Understand and apply innovative frameworks, concepts and tools to strategically managing projects in organizations. Assess the value of Project Value Management by understanding the limitations of classic approaches to project management. Use the project value paradigm to manage projects strategically at the levels of planning, execution, and control towards achieving value. Develop a project strategy to maximize the project’s value for key shareholders and stakeholders. Select the appropriate set of tools to manage projects strategically. Understand and differentiate between project risks and project uncertainties.
    Prerequisites: MGT -609 EM -612 SYS -612 SDOE-612 PME -609 IPD -612 ME -636 Orientation Week The Core Conflict of Classic and Value Project Management The Impact of Project Risks and Project Uncertainties Project Manager's Value Mindset Definition of Project Value Proposition Definition of Project Value Scorecard Relations between Project Variation and Project Value Client Perspective: Stakeholder Analysis and Evaluation Client Perspective: Identifying Needs Client Perspective: Prioritizing Needs Resource Perspective: Critical Chain Single Project Level Resource Perspective: Critical Chain Multi Project Level Resource Perspective: Critical Chain Risk Management Project Perspective: Project Value Statement Final Presentations Final Case Due Critical Chain by Eliyahu M. Goldratt.  Homework 1 Team assignment related to course content. Homework 2 Team assignment related to course content. Final Project Development of a project value statement. Midterm Exam Timed exam covering course materials. Final Exam Timed exam covering course materials.  participation: 20% assignments: 20% exams: 20% projects: 20% quizzes: 10% final: 10%  attendance: Class attendance is recorded for every lecture. text:
Course: Probability and Statistics for Systems Engineering (SYS 501)
    Semester:  
    Credits: 3.0
    Instructor: Christian Sprague
    Description: This course is designed for students with a background in engineering, technology, or science who have not taken a class in statistics or need a refresher class.
    Learning Outcomes: Understand and apply probability distributions to a variety of data sets. Understand statistics associated with probability distributions. Understand concepts of confidence intervals. Apply hypothesis testing. Understand basic simulation steps.
    Prerequisites: Visualizing Data Probability Basics Modeling Uncertainty with Discrete Probability Distributions Modeling Uncertainty with Continuous Probability Distributions Joint Probabilities Generating Simulated Data Inferential Statistics Hypothesis Testing and Analysis of Variance Design of Experiments for Data Collection Data-Driven System Modeling Bayesian Statistics (Part 1) Bayesian Statistics (Part 2) Decision Analysis Probability and statistics for engineering and the sciences by Devore, J. L..   participation: 13% assignments: 33.5% exams: 34% quizzes: 6.5% final: 18%  attendance: Attendance is mandatory for live sessions. late_work: Late assignments are penalized 10% per day and will not be accepted after solutions are posted. academic_integrity: Collaboration is allowed on homework provided each student completes their own work.
