Course: Systems Integration (SYS605WS)
    Semester: Spring 2024
    Credits: 
    Instructor: Walter Lucchesi
    Description: This course provides an understanding of systems integration, approaches to architect, design, implement, verify, and validate integrated systems.
    Learning Outcomes: Understand the relationship between system architecture and system integration. Understand the relationship between system requirements and verification testing. Understand the relationship between stakeholder needs and system validation. Develop plans for systematically integrating a complex system. Represent needs of integration, verification and validation needs early in the system lifecycle. Design effective verification and validation systems. Design verification tests to ensure that system specifications are met. Design validation tests to demonstrate that customer and stakeholder needs are fully met. Utilize a wide range of testing methods and tools.
    Prerequisites: SYS625 SYS650  The Engineering Design of Systems: Models and Methods by Dennis M. Buede and William D. Miller. Applied Space Systems Engineering by Larson, Kirkpatrick, Sellers, Thomas and Verma. Model-based integration and testing of complex high-tech systems by Jan Tretmans (Editor).   participation: 15% assignments: 30% projects: 35% final: 20%  late_work: Contact the instructor to discuss late submissions. academic_integrity: All students must adhere to the Graduate Student Code of Academic Integrity. accommodations: Students with documented disabilities can receive accommodations through the Office of Disability Services.

Course: Modeling and Simulation (SYS 611)
    Semester: Spring 2024
    Credits: 
    Instructor: Dr. Robert Edson
    Description: This course emphasizes the development of modeling and simulation concepts and analysis skills necessary to design, program, implement, and use computers to solve complex systems/products analysis problems.
    Learning Outcomes: Examine classic and modern (state-of-the-art) modeling and simulation methods and techniques. Analyze socio-technical challenges and problems to determine appropriate modeling techniques. Apply the methods, processes, and tools needed to perform effective and efficient modeling and simulation on complex projects/programs. Conduct analysis of real-world data and complex problems. Describe the role of modeling and simulation within the systems engineering and the system development lifecycle.
    Prerequisites: Graduate Status or approved by advisor and instructor Introductions Course Overview Modeling and Simulation Overview Excel as a power modeling tool Spreadsheet best practices Overview of Model Types Modeling in Systems Engineering System Thinking Overview The Modeling and Simulation Approach Defining the Problem Describing the Related System Probability Distributions The need randomness in simulations Random Numbers Random Variates and Process Generators The Components of a Robust Simulation Conceptual Models Models and Experiments Determining the Appropriate Modeling Approach Overview of Production and Process Systems Discrete Event Simulations Monte Carlo Simulations System Dynamics Modeling Overview of Complex Systems Agent Based Models Queueing Systems Queueing Models Verification vs Validation V&V approaches V&V across the entire Modeling and Simulation Process Modeling and Simulation in Socio-Technical Systems Article Review Multi-Modeling Approach Multi-modeling Case Studies Advanced Modeling Approaches and Applications Domain specific modeling approaches Gaming Modeling System of Systems Final Project Presentation Part I  Discussion Forums Students will explore topics through online discussions. Each discussion will be initiated with a framing post and questions. Students will respond to the questions and comment critically on other posts. Individual Homework To help reinforce the material covered in the modules, homework assignments will be assigned. The homework will include questions and problems related to the course materials and the development of simple models and simulations. Modeling and Simulation Article Review Each student will complete a review of a modeling and simulation journal article highlighting one of the modeling and simulation approaches. Class Project The class project will assess the learning from all modules. The student group will address a problem of their choosing. Project Related Homework Throughout the course, the student groups will complete parts of the project as homework assignments. Final Project Presentation and Report At the conclusion of the project, a report will be prepared by the student groups to summarize their work.  participation: 10% assignments: 20% projects: 30%  attendance: Attendance in live class sessions is beneficial and students should attend if possible. late_work: Assignments received 1-6 days late will have 20% of the total points deducted; assignments received more than one week late will have 50% of the total points deducted. academic_integrity: Students in this course are bound by the Stevens Graduate Student Code of Academic Integrity. accommodations: Stevens Institute of Technology is dedicated to providing appropriate accommodations to students with documented disabilities.

Course: Designing Space Missions and Systems (SYS 632)
    Semester: Fall 2023
    Credits: 
    Instructor: Prof Pam Magee
    Description: This course examines the real-world application of the entire space systems engineering discipline to robotic space mission design.
    Learning Outcomes: Enhanced understanding of the big picture for space missions and systems Working, technical knowledge of how the elements of a space mission work, how the functions of a space system are implemented in practice, and the key trades that lead to a successful mission Practical experience with using data and systems engineering processes in the Space Technology Series to develop conceptual designs for space missions and systems An organized framework for future space learning—on your own, in academic courses, or other short courses
    Prerequisites: Course Intro Applied Space Systems Engineering Space Mission Design Intro to Orbits and Trajectories Space Environments Understanding Orbits Describing and Using Orbits Orbit Maneuvers Orbit Design and Selection Ascent /Entry Launch System Services Spacecraft Architecture Development Payload Design Spacecraft Allocated Architecture Spacecraft Subsystem Design Subsystem Design (Electrical Power, ADCS/GNC) Subsystem Design (Space Propulsion, Communications) Subsystem Design (Data Handling) Subsystem Design (Thermal Control, Spacecraft Structures & Configuration) System Realization Space Mission Operations Evaluating Mission Risk and Cost Review Core Capabilities for Space Mission Analysis and Design by SMAD Core. Understanding Space: An Introduction to Astronautics by Sellers, et al.. course_title: Human Spaceflight Mission Analysis and Design
text:
Course: Human Spaceflight Mission Analysis and Design (SYS 635)
    Semester: Spring 2023
    Credits: 
    Instructor: Prof. Pam Magee
    Description: This course is designed to provide the conceptual framework for developing crewed space missions starting from a blank sheet of paper.
    Learning Outcomes: Summarize human spaceflight mission design principles, limitations and processes and apply them to develop goals, objectives as well as top level requirements Describe the physiological and psychological limitations and challenges for humans to live and work and space Explain basic principles of orbital mechanics and how they apply to human missions. Apply these principles to calculate and analyze trajectory and orbit maneuver options for different mission concepts. Describe and apply space element architectures, design and sizing principles and processes for on-orbit, ascent and re-entry operations. Apply sizing principles to estimate mass and power for a given set of requirements. Characterize the scope, functions and physical architecture options for human spaceflight support systems such as Environmental Control and Life Support, Thermal Control, EVA Systems and others. Apply sizing principles to estimate mass and power for a given set of requirements. Discuss scope, functions and requirements for mission operations elements including Operations Planning; command, control and communications (C3); Logistics; and in-situ resource utilization (ISRU).
    Prerequisites: Designing Human Space Missions Safety of Human Space Missions Space Environments Physiology of Human Spaceflight Human Factors and Psychology International Crewed Missions Understanding Orbits Describing and Using Orbits Maneuvering and Rendezvous Entry, Descent, Landing and Ascent Designing and Sizing Space Elements Designing and Sizing Transfer Vehicles Cost Estimating Review for Midterm Exam Finish Case Study 1 Reviews Thermal Control Environmental Control and Life Support Crew ADCS/GNC Electrical Power Data Handling Structures Space Propulsion EVA Systems Mission Operations Command, Control and Communications Logistics Support In-Situ Resources Human Spaceflight Mission Analysis and Design by Larson and Pranke. Understanding Space: An Introduction to Astronautics by Sellers, et al.. Course: Systems Architecture & Design (SYS 650)
    Semester: Summer 2023/2024
    Credits: 
    Instructor: Dr. Don Schlomer
    Description: System Architecture and Design describes the fundamentals of system architectures and the architecting process, including practical heuristics for developing good architectures.
    Learning Outcomes: Understand the link between the functional and physical system architectures and the iterative nature of architecture development. Apply a process for flowing down or allocating system level requirements to components level requirements through equivalence, apportionment, synthesis and other methods. Apply the experience gained through the use of a systems engineering based tool that supports systems engineering requirements, architecture and modeling processes. Develop an architecture applying the methods learned in the course. Understand the strategic role of architecting, and the value of functional modeling.
    Prerequisites: Fundamentals of Systems Engineering (SYS 625) Introduction and Course Overview What to Build What to Build Why Build it this way Why Build it this way Intro to GENSYS Overview of System Architecture Overview of System Architecture Strategic Perspective of Architecture Functional Decomposition Team’s Project Presentations in Class Functional Decomposition Functional Flows & Analysis Physical Architecture Applied Space Systems Engineering by Larson, et al.. Course: Decision and Risk Analysis for Complex Systems (SYS 660)
    Semester: Fall 2024
    Credits: 
    Instructor: Earl Sprague
    Description: The ability to structure and analyze an effective trade study under conditions of uncertainty and risk is a core systems engineering skill.
    Learning Outcomes: Define a decision Explain the basics of probability theory important to decision making Recognize factors contributing to successful and unsuccessful decisions Apply a simple model for decision making Discern the difference between a well-framed problem and a poorly-framed one Utilize at least two techniques for generating alternatives Apply at least three techniques for deciding a course of action Define risk and opportunity Set up a risk/opportunity management plan Define the difference between risk and issues Structure and solve decision problems using an engineering trade study approach

Course: Decision and Risk Analysis (SYS 660)
    Semester:  
    Credits: 3
    Instructor: Safa El Kefi
    Description: The ability to structure and analyze an effective trade study under conditions of uncertainty and risk is a core systems engineering skill. This course addresses the foundations of decision analysis and probability theory that are relevant to systems engineers.
    Learning Outcomes: Develop a fundamental objective hierarchy or value tree to solve a decision. Solve decision problems using decision trees, expected value, influence diagrams, Pugh Matrix, and engineering trade studies. Incorporate risk management into the decision-making process to prevent unintended negative consequences and to take advantage of opportunities. Formulate strategies to avoid negative consequences and potential impacts of human behavior on decision making. Discuss factors contributing to successful and unsuccessful decisions. Apply decision making process steps to maximize success.
    Prerequisites: Overall course content and requirements Introduction to course Probability & Statistics Monte Carlo Simulation Decision Trees Bayes Law Decision Analysis Flow Chart Framing issues Fundamental Objective Hierarchy Means Objective Network Alternatives Idea Generation Techniques Influence Diagrams Decision Tree Application Single and multi-criteria problems Utility Theory Want & Must Have Criteria Utility Table & Curve Pairwise comparison Evaluation Scoring AHP Model Cognitive Bias Prospect Theory Human Impacts Risk Management Process Risk Mgmt Planning Risk Identification Qualitative Analysis Quantitative Risk Analysis Risk Register Threat Handling Strategies Opportunity Handling Strategies Risk Leverage Risk Monitoring Pugh Matrix Choosing a solution Engineering Trade Study Simple Sensitivity Analysis One-way sensitivity Tornado Diagram Two-way sensitivity What is Game Theory Impact on decisions Relevant factors Blink: The Power of Thinking Without Thinking by Malcolm Gladwell.   participation: 13% assignments: 25% projects: 25% quizzes: 10% final: 12%  attendance: Attendance at the live sessions is mandatory and will be graded. late_work: If a student needs an extension, the instructor should be contacted ahead of the due date. academic_integrity: All Stevens graduate students promise to be fully truthful and avoid dishonesty, fraud, misrepresentation, and deceit of any type in relation to their academic work. accommodations: Stevens Institute of Technology is dedicated to providing appropriate accommodations to students with documented disabilities.

Course: Forecasting and Demand Modeling (SYS 670)
    Semester: Summer 2024
    Credits: 3 credits
    Instructor: Dr. Teresa Zigh
    Description: This course builds analytical skills for developing mathematical models for decision-making concentrating specifically on time series data. It covers the theory and application of modeling demand and consumer behavior using statistical methods for analysis and forecasting for facilities, services, and products.
    Learning Outcomes: Understand the conceptual underpinnings of methods in time-series forecasting Be familiar with forecasting precision validation measures and be able to use the measures as guidelines for model design and development Select appropriate models based on theoretical standards, and judge the suitability of models based on the assessment of performance and usability Use available software analysis tools with ease, and to select appropriate tools for various analyses and situations.
    Prerequisites: Knowledge of probability and statistics Intro to Forecasting Statistical Background for Forecasting Regression Analysis Regression Analysis Problem Session Exponential Smoothing Methods Exponential Smoothing Problem Session Midterm Exam ARIMA Modeling I & II ARIMA Modeling Problem Session ARIMA Modeling III ARIMA Modeling Biosurveillance Transfer Function Noise Models & Intervention Analysis Alternative Forecasting Techniques Introduction to Time Series Analysis and Forecasting by Montgomery, Jennings, Kulahci. Course: Space Missions Operations (SYS 637)
    Semester: Spring 2024
    Credits: 
    Instructor: 
    Description: This course explores the challenge of designing and implementing real-world mission operations in a practical, cost-effective way.
    Learning Outcomes: Define and explain the critical activities of space mission operations Discuss the inputs, outputs and uses for a space Mission Operations Concept and be able to critically analyze one of these key documents Describe the elements that contribute to mission operations complexity and perform trade-off analyses to reduce that complexity Analyze mission orbits to determine ground system pass characteristics Describe key elements of mission ground systems Compare and contrast operations concepts for military, civil, scientific and human space missions Develop and analyze aspects of simulated satellite pass plans
    Prerequisites: Course Intro Mission Operations Overview Falconsat Case Study Failure is Not an Option video ConOps Overview ConOps Development Operations complexity Cygnus Case Study QuickLook (QL) ConOps Overview Understanding and Using Orbits pt 1 Understanding and Using Orbits pt 2 Perturbations & Orbit Prediction STK Introduction STK Tutorial STK OPS Scenarios 1 & 2 TT & C Communication Architecture / Link Analysis Ground Systems & Comm Architecture Space Environment & Spacecraft Design Contingency Planning & Anomalies Echo Star Case Study Launch & EO Ops Planning & Execution Organization & Training Take Home Final Exam Cost-Effective Space Mission Operations by Squibb et al.. Course: Augmented Intelligence and Generative AI (BIA 662)
    Semester:  
    Credits: 
    Instructor: Dr. Chris Asakiewicz
    Description: This course explores the area of augmented intelligence and its implications for today’s world of big data analytics and evidence-based decision making.
    Learning Outcomes: Understand and discuss what augmented intelligence and generative AI is, and how it differs from traditional approaches. Plan and use the primary tools associated with augmented intelligence and generative AI. Plan and execute a project that leverages augmented intelligence and generative AI. Understand and discuss the business implications of augmented intelligence and generative AI.
    Prerequisites: Introduction to Cognitive Computing AI, ML, and the Cognitive Enterprise Tools for Building Cognitive Applications Tools for Building Deep Learning Applications Perspectives on Cognitive Computing and Systems Big Data and Augmented Intelligence Building Knowledge-Based Agents Knowledge-Based Agents and Cognitive Analytics Knowledge-Based Agents and Cognitive Systems Cognitive Analytics and Evidence-Based Decision Making Cognitive Systems in Marketing, Sales, Customer Support Building Cognitive Applications – Ethics The Future of Cognitive Systems Augmented Intelligence: The Business Power of Human-Machine Collaboration by Hurwitz, J. et.al.. Machine Learning for Decision Makers: Cognitive Computing Fundamentals for Better Decision Making by Kashyap, P.. Cognitive Computing with IBM Watson, Build smart applications using artificial intelligence as a service by High, R. and Bakshi, T..  Watson Assistant Watson Discovery Watson Studio Watson Visual Deep Learning Fundamentals Deep Learning with Tensorflow Cognitive Analytics - Deep Learning Cognitive Systems – Deep QA     participation: 10% assignments: 60% projects: 30%  attendance: Attendance at live sessions counts as 10% of your grade. academic_integrity: Cheating during in-class tests or take-home examinations or homework is illegal and immoral.
